ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Local planning agency, § 2-57 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-37. - Establishment. 
    All boards, groups and committees shall be established by action of the commission. This action may be by way of ordinance, resolution or motion, whichever is appropriate under the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 54, § 1, 6-13-1979) 
Sec. 2-38. - Purpose, duties and duration. 
    When establishing the boards, groups and committees, the commission shall set forth the purpose, duties, duration and procedures of the boards, groups and committees. 
(Ord. No. 54, § 2, 6-13-1979) 
Sec. 2-39. - Appointments. 
(a)  All board appointments (notwithstanding any language in the enabling resolution or ordinance) shall be for terms of two (2) years beginning on the third Wednesday of November 2008; provided that vacancies shall occur as set forth in section 2-40. The terms of all board members serving as of the date of adoption of this section shall terminate on the third Wednesday of November 2008; except that if a successor is not appointed, then that board member shall serve until an appointment is made. The board appointments of an individual commissioner shall automatically be appointed upon nomination by the appropriate commissioner; at large appointees must be approved by a majority of those members of the commission in attendance at the meeting. All appointments shall serve until a successor is appointed; notwithstanding any language herein to the contrary. 
(b)  Appointees shall be residents of the city. This provision shall not preclude the city commission from waiving the residency requirement when a board it establishes requires unique experience or qualifications. 
(c)  Appointees shall not, at the time of appointment, hold membership on any other city board, committee or commission. 
(d)  All applicants for appointment to boards shall submit a fully completed application to the city clerk listing their qualifications, areas of interest, current residence address and telephone number. Applicants shall make themselves available to city commission members for personal interviews prior to appointment. The city commission shall consider the knowledge, relevant experience and education of the applicant in its appointments. This requirement may be waived by a majority vote of the city commission. 
(e)  Members of the board shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(Ord. No. 54, § 3, 6-13-1979; Ord. No. 90-21, § 1, 11-7-1990; Ord. No. 2008-01, § 1, 2-6-2008; Ord. No. 2008-28, § 2, 1-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-40. - Vacancies. 
(a)  Upon a vacancy occurring in any board appointment, the vacancy shall be filled by the commissioner who made the appointment or a majority of the city commissioners attending a meeting for at large appointments. If the city commissioner who made the appointment is no longer serving, his/her successor shall make the appointment, or if the commission vacancy has not yet been filled as proscribed by the Charter, the city commission shall appoint the replacement by a majority vote of the city commissioners attending the meeting; said appointment shall be valid until the successor city commissioner is appointed or elected. For all individual appointments, the term of the appointee shall be deemed to end when the appointing commissioner leaves office, thereby creating a vacancy to be filled as proscribed herein. 
(b)  Appointments to the board to fill vacancies due to other than expiration of terms shall be in each instance for the unexpired remainder of the term, except as set forth above. 
(c)  Any member who is absent for more than two (2) regularly scheduled meetings in either the first or second year of his service, commencing with the date of appointment, shall be deemed to have vacated his position. The vacancy so created shall be placed on the next city commission agenda for appointment. The member who has vacated his position shall be eligible for reappointment. 
(Ord. No. 54, § 4, 6-13-1979; Ord. No. 2008-01, § 1, 2-6-2008; Ord. No. 2008-28, § 2, 1-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-41. - Removal. 
    All individual board appointees shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing commissioner. Said board members may be removed at any time by the appointing commissioner through the appointment of a replacement. At large board members shall serve at the pleasure of the city commission and said members may be removed and replaced at any time by a majority vote of the members of the commission in attendance at a commission meeting. 
(Ord. No. 54, § 5, 6-13-1979; Ord. No. 2008-01, § 1, 2-6-2008) 
Sec. 2-42. - Compensation. 
    The city manager shall provide appropriate staff support for the operation of any advisory board. Members shall receive no compensation except that, if members undertake actions on behalf of the city which require them to incur costs, they may apply to the city manager for reimbursement of those expenses prior to undertaking any such services. It shall be within the discretion of the city manager to provide reimbursement to such member. 
(Ord. No. 2008-28, § 2, 1-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-43. - Oath. 
    Before entering upon his or her official duties, every person appointed to an advisory board shall qualify for office by taking the oath prescribed for officeholders of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2008-28, § 2, 1-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-44. - Organization; rules of procedure. 
(a)  Annually at its first regular meeting after the city commission has appointed board members, the board shall elect from its membership a chairperson, and a vice chairperson, each to serve until qualification of a successor, elected in the year following. Officers of the board so elected shall be eligible to succeed themselves. 
(b)  The board shall adopt reasonable rules for the conduct of its business consistent with this article and other applicable law, and such rules shall be published and be made available to the public. 
(c)  Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or the city manager or his/her designee, at such other times as the board may determine, or as otherwise provided by law. Special meetings shall not be held unless at least twenty-four (24) hours' notice is given to each member and the city manager. 
(d)  Members shall notify the board liaison if they are unable to attend a meeting. The board liaison shall notify the alternate that his/her attendance is required. If a quorum will not be present, the board liaison shall notify the chairperson, who may cancel the scheduled meeting. 
(e)  All meetings shall be open to the public. 
(f)  Minutes shall be kept of the proceeding at each meeting which shall record the official actions taken by the board. An audio tape recording of the proceedings may be available. 
(Ord. No. 2008-28, § 2, 1-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-45. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKS AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 90-10, §§ 1-3, adopted Aug. 15, 1990 did not specifically amend the Code; hence, the provisions set hereinabove were codified as Div. 2, §§ 2-46-2-48 at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Park regulations, § 11-69 et seq. 

Sec. 2-46. - Created; services provided. 
    The City of Parkland Parks and Recreation Advisory Board is hereby created. The board shall be responsible for providing the following advisory services to the city commission: 
(1)  Recommendations as to size and locations of public parks in the city. 
(2)  Recommendations as to the facilities to be provided at public parks in the city. 
(3)  Recommendations as to the establishment of parks and recreations systems and programs for the citizens of the city. 
(4)  Recommendations on other matters involving recreational services and facilities as may be requested from time to time by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, § 1, 8-15-1990; Ord. No. 91-8, § 2, 4-17-1991) 
Sec. 2-47. - Members. 
    The parks and recreation advisory board shall consist of seven (7) regular members and two (2) alternate members who shall be residents of the city. Each member of the city commission shall have the right to appoint one (1) member to the board and there shall be two (2) at large appointments. The two (2) alternates shall be chosen at large. All non at large members shall serve two-year terms and alternates and at large members shall serve one-year terms. If the commissioner's term lapses and no appointment is made for his/her position on the board, a board member shall serve until his/her successor is appointed. The board shall appoint a chairman and vice-chairman from among its members. The board shall develop and adopt rules of procedure except that in all cases, the majority of the members shall constitute a quorum and no action may be taken by the board except through an affirmative vote of a majority of those members in attendance. Until such other rules of procedure are adopted, Robert's Rules of Order shall be followed at all meetings. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, § 2, 8-15-1990; Ord. No. 91-8, § 3, 4-17-1991; Ord. No. 2003-09, § 1, 5-7-2003; Ord. No. 2005-12, § 1, 6-1-2005) 
Sec. 2-48. - Compensation. 
    The city manager shall provide appropriate staff support for the operation of the parks and recreation advisory board. Members shall receive no compensation except that, if members undertake actions on behalf of the city which require them to incur costs, they may apply to the city manager for reimbursement of those expenses prior to undertaking any such services. It shall be within the discretion of the city manager to provide reimbursement to such member. 
(Ord. No. 90-10, § 3, 8-15-1990; Ord. No. 91-8, § 4, 4-17-1991) 
DIVISION 3. - EDUCATIONAL ADVISORY BOARD 

Sec. 2-49. - Established, membership. 
    The city commission hereby establishes a Parkland Educational Advisory Board. The board shall consist of five (5) regular members and two (2) at large members. All members of the board shall be residents of the city. Each member shall serve a term co-extensive with the commissioner appointing that member; the two (2) at large members shall serve two-year terms. There shall be two (2) alternates serving two-year terms. The board shall also sit as a special safety committee to consider matters relating to student safety and make recommendations directly to the full board on said matters. The city commission shall also appoint three (3) members who are not on the board to serve on the special safety committee; these three (3) members shall either live or work in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-30, § 1, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2007-03, § 1, 2-21-2007) 
Sec. 2-50. - Meetings, staff support. 
    The board shall meet as regularly as is deemed necessary; provided that the special safety committee shall meet at least twice a year. The city manager shall provide appropriate staff support as deemed appropriate in his discretion. The board shall operate pursuant to Robert's Rules of Order unless it adopts other specific rules of procedure. A majority of the members of the board shall constitute a quorum. The board shall appoint a chairman and co-chairman from among their membership. 
(Ord. No. 2005-30, § 2, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2007-03, § 2, 2-21-2007) 
Sec. 2-50.1. - Validity. 
    This section shall be valid for a two-year period unless extended by the city commission by resolution; if no extending resolution is adopted the provisions of this amendment shall lapse and be of no further force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 2007-03, § 3, 2-21-2007) 
Sec. 2-51. - Services provided. 
    The board shall make recommendations to the city commission with regard to matters relating to education in the city, make recommendations to improve communications between schools and school populations, to recommend projects for improving school facilities, to discuss, advise and, if they desire to, make recommendations on public school boundaries and to advise the city commission on health, safety, transportation and quality of life issues that affect students. 
(Ord. No. 2005-30, § 3, 2-1-2006; Ord. No. 2006-20, § 1, 8-9-2006; Ord. No. 2007-03, § 1, 2-21-2007) 
DIVISION 4. - CODE ENFORCEMENT PROCEDURE WITH SPECIAL MAGISTRATE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2, adopted Nov. 5, 2008, set out provisions intended for use as Div. 5, §§ 2-29-2-37. For purposes of classification to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as Div. 4, §§ 2-52-2-52.8. 

Sec. 2-52. - Intent. 
    It shall be the intent of this chapter to provide a fair and expeditious process to enforce the city's zoning and technical codes and to correct violations thereof in a manner consistent with all the procedures, requirements and remedies provided for in Chapter 162, Florida Statutes (2005), as amended. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include future; words in the plural number include the singular number and vice versa. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
    City means City of Parkland, Florida. 
    City commission means the City of Parkland, Florida Commission. 
    Code means collectively the City of Parkland, Code of Ordinances. 
    Code inspector means any authorized agent or employee of the city whose duty it is to assure compliance with the codes. 
    Manager means the city manager. 
    Notice means a civil violation issued to a violator in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
    Repeat violation means a violation of a provision of the Code by a person whom the code enforcement special master (or the code enforcement board) has previously found to have violated the same provision of the Code within five (5) years prior to the current violation. 
    Special magistrate means a person appointed by the city commission to perform all duties and powers outlined in this division. (All references in any resolution or ordinance to special master shall be deemed to refer to the special magistrate.) 
    Uncorrectable violation means a violation, which is irreparable or irreversible in nature, and which cannot be remedied after the violation has been committed because the violation constitutes a single prohibited act rather than an ongoing condition or circumstance. 
    Violator means that person or entity responsible for a violation of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-29), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.1. - Qualifications of code enforcement special magistrate; appointment and removal; compensation. 
(a)  Appointments of code enforcement special magistrate shall be made by the city commission upon the recommendation of the city manager as needed on the basis of experience or interest in code enforcement. 
(b)  Special magistrate shall be active or retired member of the Florida Bar with at least five (5) years of experience. 
(c)  Appointments shall be made for a term of two (2) years by the city commission. 
(d)  Code enforcement special magistrate shall not be city employees but may be compensated at a rate to be determined by the manager, subject to approval by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-30), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.2. - Code enforcement special magistrate jurisdiction and authority. 
(a)  The code enforcement special magistrate ("special magistrate") shall have the jurisdiction and authority to hear and decide alleged violations of the following: 
(1)  The city zoning ordinances, the land development code as it exists today and as may be amended from time to time, and all ordinances relating to the development, maintenance, use, construction or condition of real property, building or structures within the city. 
(2)  All city building codes, including, but not limited to, the Florida Building Code. 
(3)  All city fire codes and any other city ordinances to the extent permitted by law. 
(4)  In addition to the powers and authority given to the code enforcement special masters for the city pursuant to this chapter, the city may, in its discretion, exercise any powers given to municipalities or their special magistrates by Florida Statutes, Chapter 162, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-31), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.3. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsections (b) and (c), if a violation of the codes is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator and give him or her a reasonable time to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified for correction, the code inspector shall schedule a hearing. The code inspector, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing, and written notice of such hearing shall be hand delivered or mailed as provided in Section 162.12, Florida Statutes, to said violator. At the option of the code inspector, notice may additionally be served by publication or posting as provided in Florida Statutes Section 162.12. If the violation is corrected and then recurs or if the violation is not corrected by the time specified for correction by the code inspector, the case may be presented to the special master even if the violation has been corrected prior to the hearing, and the notice shall so state. 
(b)  If a repeat violation is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator but is not required to give the violator a reasonable time to correct the violation. The code inspector, upon notifying the violator of a repeat violation, shall request a hearing before the special magistrate. The special magistrate, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing and shall provide notice pursuant to Florida Statutes Section 162.12. The case may be presented to the special magistrate even if the repeat violation has been corrected prior to the hearing, and the notice shall so state. If the repeat violation has been corrected, the special master retains the right to schedule a hearing to determine costs and impose the payment of reasonable enforcement fees upon the repeat violator. The repeat violator may choose to waive his or her rights to this hearing and pay said costs as determined by the special magistrate. 
(c)  If the code inspector has reason to believe a violation or the condition causing the violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, and welfare or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the code inspector shall make a reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the special magistrate and request a hearing. 
(d)  If the owner of property that is subject to an enforcement proceeding before a special master transfers ownership of such property between the time the initial pleading was served and the time of the hearing, such owner shall: 
(1)  Disclose, in writing, the existence and the nature of the proceeding to the prospective transferee. 
(2)  Deliver to the prospective transferee a copy of the pleadings, notices, and other materials relating to the code enforcement proceeding received by the transferor. 
(3)  Disclose, in writing, to the prospective transferee that the new owner will be responsible for compliance with the applicable code and with orders issued in the code enforcement proceeding. 
(4)  File a notice with the code enforcement official of the transfer of the property, with the identity and address of the new owner and copies of the disclosures made to the new owner, within five (5) days after the date of the transfer. 
A failure to make the disclosures described in paragraphs (1), (2), and (3) before the transfer creates a rebuttal presumption of fraud. If the property is transferred before the hearing, the proceeding shall not be dismissed, but the new owner shall be provided a reasonable period of time to correct the violation before the hearing is held. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-31), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.4. - Conduct of hearing. 
(a)  Upon request of the code inspector, or at such other times as may be necessary, the special master shall schedule a hearing. Minutes shall be kept of all hearings and all hearings and proceedings shall be open to the public. The local governing body shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the special magistrate. 
(b)  Each case before the special magistrate shall be presented by the local governing body attorney or by a member of the administrative staff of the local governing body. If the local governing body prevails in prosecuting a case before the special magistrate, it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in prosecuting the case before the special magistrate and such costs may be included in the lien authorized under Section 162.09(3), Florida Statutes. 
(c)  A special magistrate shall proceed to hear the cases on the agenda for that day. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The special magistrate shall take testimony from the code inspector and alleged violator. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. 
(d)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the special magistrate shall issue findings of fact, based on evidence of record and conclusions of law, and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with powers granted herein. The order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date and that a fine may be imposed and, under the conditions specified in Section 162.09(1), Florida Statutes, the cost of repairs may be included along with the fine if the order is not complied with by said date. A certified copy of such order may be recorded in the public records of the county and shall constitute notice to any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns if the violation concerns real property, and the findings therein shall be binding upon the violator and, if the violation concerns real property, any subsequent purchasers, successors in interest, or assigns. If an order is recorded in the public records pursuant to this subsection and the order is complied with by the date specified in the order, the special magistrate shall issue an order acknowledging compliance that it shall be recorded in the public records. A hearing is not required to issue such an order acknowledging compliance. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-33), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.5. - Powers of special magistrates. 
    The special magistrate shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings. 
(2)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings. Subpoenas may be served by the sheriff of the county or police department of the municipality. 
(3)  Subpoena evidence to its hearings. 
(4)  Take testimony under oath. 
(5)  Issue orders having the force of law to command whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
(6)  To exercise all authority as granted to special magistrates in Section 162.03(2), Florida Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-34), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.6. - Administrative fines; costs of repair; liens. 
(a)  A special magistrate, upon notification by the code inspector that an order of the special magistrate has not been complied with by the set time or upon finding that a repeat violation has been committed, may order the violator to pay a fine in an amount specified in this section for each day the violation continues past the date set by the special magistrate for compliance or, in the case of a repeat violation, for each day the repeat violation continues, beginning with the date the repeat violation is found to have occurred by the code inspector. In addition, if the violation is a violation described in Florida Statutes Section 162.06(4), the special magistrate shall notify the local governing body, which may make all reasonable repairs which are required to bring the property into compliance and charge the violator with the reasonable cost of the repairs along with the fine imposed pursuant to this section. Making such repairs does not create a continuing obligation on the part of the local governing body to make further repairs or to maintain the property and does not create any liability against the local governing body for any damages to the property if such repairs were completed in good faith. If a finding of a violation or a repeat violation has been made as provided in this part, a hearing shall not be necessary for issuance of the order imposing the fine. If, after due notice and hearing, the special magistrate finds a violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature, it may order the violator to pay a fine as specified in subsection (b)(1). 
(b)  (1)  A fine imposed pursuant to this section shall not exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day for a first violation and shall not exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for a repeat violation, and in addition, may include all costs of repairs pursuant to subsection (a). However, if the special magistrate finds the violation to be irreparable or irreversible in nature, it may impose a fine not to exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) per violation. A special magistrate may impose additional fines to cover costs incurred by the city in enforcing its codes and the costs of all repairs undertaken. 
(2)  In determining the amount of the fine, if any, the special magistrate shall consider the following factors: 
a.  The gravity of the violation; 
b.  Any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation; and 
c.  Any previous violations committed by the violator. 
(c)  A certified copy of an order imposing a fine, or a fine plus repair costs, may be recorded in the public records and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists and upon any other real personal property owned by the violator. Upon petition to the circuit court, such order shall be enforceable in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of this state, including execution and levy against the personal property of the violator, but such order shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. A fine imposed pursuant to this part shall continue to accrue until the violator comes into compliance or until judgment is rendered in a suit filed pursuant to this section, whichever occurs first. A lien arising from a fine imposed pursuant to this section runs in favor of the local governing body, and the local governing body may execute a satisfaction or release of lien entered pursuant to this section. After three (3) months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the enforcement board may authorize the local governing body attorney to foreclose on the lien or to sue to recover a money judgment for the amount of the lien plus accrued interest. No lien created pursuant to the provisions of this part may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under § 4, Art. X of the State Constitution. The money judgment provisions of this section shall not apply to real property or personal property which is covered under § (4)(a), Art. X of the State Constitution. A code enforcement lien shall have priority over all liens except those for ad valorem taxes. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-35), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.7. - Duration of lien. 
    Liens shall have the duration as provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-36), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.8. - Notices. 
    Notices shall be given in compliance with F.S. § 162.12, (2007) as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2008-31, § 2(2-37), 11-5-2008) 
Sec. 2-52.9. - Mitigation of code liens. 
(a)  Any respondent, against whom a fine or lien has been imposed pursuant to section 2-52.6, and who has cured the violation as determined by the city, may petition in writing (in a form determined by the city) the code enforcement special master for mitigation of the fine/lien. Any mitigation request shall be filed with the city clerk who shall forward it to the special master. The city clerk shall schedule the matter for hearing as the earliest possible special master meeting. Any request shall contain the circumstances which the applicant believes justifies the mitigation of the lien and shall address the factors for mitigation as forth below. The city commission shall set a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to file any request; said fee shall be paid at the time of the request. 
(b)  In making a determination with regard to an application for mitigation of a fine/lien, the code enforcement special master shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The length of time that has elapsed since a violation was determined to exist on the property by the special master; and 
(2)  The length of time the violation existed passed the time for compliance; and 
(3)  The difficulty in remedying the condition which led to the code enforcement violation; and 
(4)  Whether the violation was a repeat offense; and 
(5)  The severity of the code violation and its impact upon the public health, safety and welfare and the negative effects on the aesthetics of the city or the neighboring community; and 
(6)  Costs incurred by the city in prosecuting or otherwise responding to the code violation case; and 
(7)  The costs incurred by the applicant in remedying the violation and the quality of remedy affected; and 
(8)  The number of existing or previous code violations found or notice of code violations issued for the property in the past five (5) years; and 
(9)  Such other equitable and/or legal considerations as the committee may find are appropriate. 
(c)  The special master shall not consider the impact of the mitigation request on the prospective sale of the property. 
(d)  The code enforcement special master shall hold a hearing on the mitigation request at which the applicant may present witnesses in his/her favor and the city may present witnesses which it believes are relevant to the request. Further, members of the public may speak on the request. Only evidence germane to the request and the standards set forth above shall be considered by the special master in making his/her determination. 
(e)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the special master shall render its decision and the application in writing. 
(Ord. No. 2013-15, § 1, 9-18-2013; Ord. No. 2014-01, § 1, 2-5-2014) 
DIVISION 5. - RESERVED[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, adopted Oct. 7, 2009, set out provisions intended for use as Div. 4 and Div. 5, §§ 2-53-2-60. Subsequently, § 2-53 has been renumbered as § 2-61.

DIVISION 6. - LOCAL PLANNING AGENCY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, adopted Oct. 7, 2009, set out provisions intended for use as Div. 4 and Div. 5, §§ 2-53-2-60. For purposes of classification and to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion with the city's concurrence, these provisions have been included as Div. 5 and Div. 6, §§ 2-53-2-60. Subsequently, § 2-53 has been renumbered as § 2-61. 

Sec. 2-57. - Designation. 
    Pursuant to F.S. § 163.3167, the planning and zoning board of the city is hereby designated and established as the local planning agency of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, 10-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-58. - Function. 
(a)  The community development department of the city is hereby directed to prepare the comprehensive plan and any amendments thereto, and forward same to the local planning agency for their review. 
(b)  The functions of the local planning agency are to review, revise, and or propose any amendments to the comprehensive plan of the city after hearings to be held upon due public notice and to make recommendations to the commission regarding the adoption of amendments to the plan, or elements or portions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, 10-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-59. - Rules of procedure; membership; staff. 
    The rules of procedure, composition, officers, financial support and staffing for the local planning agency shall be the same as the rules of procedure presently in effect for the planning and zoning board except as noted below. 
    Consistent with F.S. § 163.3174, a representative of the Broward County School Board shall be permitted to serve on the City of Parkland's Local Planning Agency in a nonvoting capacity to the extent authorized by any existing interlocal agreement between the two (2) jurisdictions. 
(Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, 10-7-2009) 
Sec. 2-60. - Meetings. 
(a)  All meetings of the local planning agency shall be public meetings, and the records of the same shall be public records. 
(b)  It is the intention of the commission that the planning and zoning board's hearings and procedures shall give the widest opportunities for public comments and discussion. 
(Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, 10-7-2009) 
ARTICLE V. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) ---

State Law reference- Unemployment compensation, F.S. Ch. 443; workers' compensation law, F.S. Ch. 440; age discrimination in employment, F.S. § 112.044; code of ethics, F.S. § 112.311 et seq.; oath, F.S. § 876.05; political activities, F.S. § 104.31; collective bargaining law, F.S. Ch. 447. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-61. - Travel policy. 
    The provisions of this section are intended to be in partial substitution of the provisions of F.S. Section 112.061 or any successor to such statute. 
(a)  Payment of expenses; exceptions to state statute. The city will pay the reasonable travel expenses of the city commission members, officers, and employees incurred in connection with authorized city travel. It is the intent of the city commission to follow F.S. Section 112.061, with the following exceptions: Relating to subsection (6) Rates of Per Diem and Subsistence Allowance, (a)(1) through (b) and (d) are hereby modified to the following: 
(1)  Breakfast   $ 6.00 
(2)  Lunch      $ 8.00 
(3)  Dinner     $14.00 
(4)  Lodging shall be based upon the group rate as indicated in conference brochure, if applicable; or, based on actual costs for lodging at a single-occupancy rate which is substantiated by paid bills therefor. 
(5)  With respect to mileage allowance for the use of the privately owned vehicles, the allowance shall be based upon the existing rate established by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). 
Alternative: A traveler on official city business which requires overnight lodging may request a per diem payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for lodging and meals in lieu of submitting receipts for such lodging and meals. The traveler shall be reimbursed one-fourth (1/4) of the authorized per diem rate of the travel day pursuant to F.S. Section 112.061, subsection 5(a). 
(b)  Advance travel authorization and advancement of funds. Persons shall obtain authorization for city travel, and, if needed, an advance of funds for use on the trip, by completing a travel estimate of expenses form and obtaining approval by the department director, the finance department with respect to availability of funds, and the city manager. The travel forms are available in the finance department. 
No advancement of funds shall be made for persons who are accompanying an authorized travel but who are not on official city business themselves. If, as a matter of convenience, the authorized traveler wishes the city to make travel arrangements for such persons, all costs of the travel arrangements shall be paid to the city before the city proceeds with such arrangements. 
(c)  Filing of travel expense and settlements forms. At the conclusion of the trip, the traveler must submit a travel expense and settlement form to the city manager. This settlement shall be accompanied by receipts and other documents in support of expenses set forth thereon. Regardless of whether or not an advance was received, this travel expense and settlement form shall be filed within forty (40) days of the traveler's return. If the travel expense and settlement form is not filed within forty (40) days, the city shall not reimburse expenses and, in the case of an undocumented advancement, shall have the right to deduct the amount of such undocumented advancement from future compensation payments. Any difference between the amount advanced and the reasonable expenses shall either be returned to the city or reimbursed to the traveler, whichever is appropriate. 
(d)  Proof of expenses. The city administration shall require proof that expenditures were actually incurred and for the authorized public purpose. All expenditures shall be substantiated by receipts and/or other supporting documentation. If adequate proof relating to any one (1) or all of the categories is not submitted, reimbursement shall not be made. The travel expense and settlement forms are to be approved by the department director, subjected to an audit by the finance department, and submitted by the city manager for review and approval. The city manager shall approve all city travel by officials and employees, except for the city commissioners, in advance. However, the city manager shall keep the commission advised of the status of the commission travel budget and year-to-date expenditures. The city commission shall approve any travel expenditures which exceed budgeted amounts. 
(Ord. No. 98-08, § 1, 4-1-1998) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, adopted Oct. 7, 2009, set out provisions intended for use as Div. 4 and Div. 5, §§ 2-53-2-60. For purposes of classification and to preserve the style of this Code, and at the editor's discretion with the city's concurrence, these provisions have been included as Div. 5 and Div. 6, §§ 2-53-2-60. Subsequently, § 2-53 has been renumbered as § 2-61. Formerly, Ord. No. 98-08, adopted Apr. 1, 1998, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of § 1 of said ordinance as § 2-53 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 2-62, 2-63. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - CITY ATTORNEY 

Sec. 2-83. - Appointment. 
    The city attorney and assistant city attorneys shall be appointed by majority vote of the commission and shall serve at their pleasure. 
(Ord. No. 51, § 1, 10-11-1978; Ord. No. 71, § 1, 10-20-1982) 
Sec. 2-84. - Qualifications. 
    The city attorney and any assistant city attorney shall be a practicing attorney and a member in good standing of the Florida Bar. 
(Ord. No. 71, § 2, 10-20-1982) 
Sec. 2-85. - Duties. 
    The city attorney shall: 
(1)  Act as legal adviser to the city and its officials in relation to their official duties; 
(2)  Provide written legal opinions an official matters when requested to do so by the commission, mayor or city manager; 
(3)  Draft and review all ordinances, resolutions, contracts, franchises or other instruments for the city; 
(4)  Represent the city in all legal actions; 
(5)  Perform whatever other duties are assigned by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 71, § 3, 10-20-1982) 
Sec. 2-86. - Assistant city attorneys-Supervision. 
    Any assistant city attorney shall serve under the direct supervision of the city attorney and shall be assigned his duties by the city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 51, § 2, 10-11-1978) 
Sec. 2-87. - Same-Duties. 
    The assistant city attorney shall have the same duties as the city attorney and shall have full authority to act in the place of the city attorney as from time to time may be necessary. 
(Ord. No. 51, § 3, 10-11-1978; Ord. No. 71, § 2, 10-20-1982) 
Sec. 2-88. - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the city attorney and assistant city attorneys shall be set by the commission. 
(Ord. No. 71, § 4, 10-20-1982) 
Secs. 2-89-2-99. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CITY MANAGER[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Charter reference- City manager, Art. V; non-interference of commission with performance of officers and employees appointed by city manager, § 5.05. 

Sec. 2-100. - Duties. 
    The city manager shall be responsible to the commission for the proper administration of all affairs of the city coming under the city manager's jurisdiction, and to that end the city manager shall: 
(1)  See that the laws, ordinances and resolutions of the city are enforced and carried out. 
(2)  Appoint, suspend, demote and/or remove any employees under the city manager's jurisdiction. 
(3)  Exercise control, direct and supervise all activities of the city government, except as otherwise provided in the Charter. 
(4)  Attend all meetings of the commission with right to take part in the discussion, but without having a vote. 
(5)  Recommend to the commission for adoption such measures as the city manager may deem necessary or expedient in the interest of the city. 
(6)  Keep the commission fully advised, not less than quarterly, as to the financial conditions and needs of the city and, at the appropriate time, submit to the commission for its consideration an annual budget. 
(7)  Advise and consult with all officers and heads of the departments of the city relative to the affairs of such departments. 
(8)  Sign all forms, contracts and agreements of the city. 
(9)  Keep all books, records and documents used by any city official or city employee. 
(10)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed under the Charter, or may be required by motion, direction, ordinance or resolution of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 73, § 1, 10-20-1982; Ord. No. 2005-20, § 1, 9-7-2005) 
Sec. 2-101. - Civil emergencies. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the content clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Abandoned vehicle means any vehicle in a wrecked, inoperative, junked, or partially dismantled condition: 
a.  Upon any public property of the city; 
b.  On any roadway of this city without the consent of the authority having jurisdiction thereof; or 
c.  Left, stored, or abandoned upon the property of another without the consent of the owner of the property. 
    City manager means the city manager, the acting city manager, or the interim city manager for the City of Parkland, or any designee of the city manager given specific authority with respect to the powers set forth herein. 
    City means the City of Parkland. 
    County means Broward County. 
    Derelict vessel means any vessel that is left, stored, or abandoned: 
a.  In a wrecked, junked, or substantially dismantled condition upon any public waters of the city; or 
b.  Docked or grounded at or beached upon the property of another without the consent of the owner of the property. 
    Disaster means the actual occurrence or threat of widespread or severe damage, injury or loss of life or property resulting from a natural or human-made causes, including, but not limited to, fire, flood, hurricane, tornado, ice/snow storm, tropical storm wind, oil spill, earthquake, explosion, water contamination, utility failure, hazardous materials or radiological incidents, epidemic, air contamination, blight, drought, infestation, hostile military action, terrorist activities, riots, or civil disorders. 
    Emergency or local emergency means any accidental, natural, or human-made event including but not limited to flood, conflagration, hazardous materials dispersal, hurricanes, tornado, earthquake, or explosion within the limits of the city resulting in an imminent threat of death or injury of persons, or the destruction of property, to such an extent that extraordinary measures must be taken to protect the public health, safety, and welfare. 
    Municipal comprehensive emergency management plan means the city's comprehensive all-hazard plan emphasizing action in the four (4) areas of the emergency management cycle: preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation. The National Incident Management System (NIMS) is used in the plan to manage and mitigate emergencies. 
    State means State of Florida. 
    Weapon means a firearm of any type, size or configuration; cutting instrument of any type, size, or configuration; tear gas gun or chemical weapon or device; electric weapon or device; or any other device or object not commonly considered a weapon but which, in its use, intended use, or threatened use, is capable of causing injury to a person (e.g., rock, bottle, stick, club, bat, etc.). 
(b)  Municipal comprehensive emergency management plan in accordance with federal, state, and county guidelines. A municipal comprehensive emergency management plan for the city (the plan) shall be administered and maintained by the city manager for the purpose of the management of emergency and disaster preparedness, response, recovery, and mitigation in accordance with current federal, state, and county guidelines. Unless otherwise designated by the city manager, the public works department shall coordinate emergency management procedures, all actions being subject to the ultimate direction of the city manager. A copy of the plan shall be on file with the city clerk. 
(c)  Authority to declare and extend a state of emergency; activation of disaster plans. A state of local emergency shall be declared by executive order of the mayor (or, in his/her absence or unavailability, the vice-mayor) if the mayor finds that an emergency, as defined in F.S. § 252.34, as amended from time to time, has occurred in the city or that the threat thereof is imminent. All executive orders issued under this subsection shall indicate the nature of the emergency, the area or areas threatened, and the conditions which have brought the emergency about or which make possible its termination. The executive order shall be promptly disseminated by means calculated to bring its contents to the attention of the general public; and, unless the circumstances attendant upon the emergency prevent or impede such filing, the order shall be filed promptly with the city clerk's office. The maximum period of any state of local emergency declared by the mayor shall be seven (7) days; thereafter, the city commission may extend the state of local emergency for an additional period of up to thirty (30) days. A majority of the commission may terminate any state of emergency declared by the mayor or city commission at any time by a vote of four (4) members of the commission. 
(d)  Clarifying and designating powers of the city manager during emergencies and disasters. 
a.  General powers. The city manager has the power to invoke any or all of the following provisions during a declared state of local emergency or disaster. Should the city manager deem it necessary to invoke any of the following provisions, a written notice will be made to the local news media for immediate dissemination to the public. All said actions shall be posted at an entrance to city hall if possible. 
1.  Alcoholic beverages. No person shall consume any alcoholic beverages in a public street or place which is publicly owned or in any motor vehicle driven or parked thereon which is within a duly designated restricted area. 
2.  Weapons. Except as permitted under state law, no person shall carry or possess any weapon in a public place or upon the property of another; such possession shall be prima facie evidence of an intent to violate the provisions of this section. 
3.  Restricted areas. No person shall enter any area designated by the city manager or his/her designee as a restricted area unless in the performance of official duties or with written permission from the city manager, or his/her designated representative, or such person shall prove residence therein. 
4.  Curfews. No person shall be allowed in the public or private streets or places throughout the city or in any designated sections of the same during the hours in which the city manager has declared a curfew, except for the provision of designated, essential services, such as fire, utilities, police, emergency medical services and hospital services, including the transportation of patients, utility emergency repairs and emergency calls by physicians. The provisions of this subsection shall not apply to government employees in the performance of essential services or while in the service of protecting the life, health, safety, property, welfare or public peace of the community. 
b.  Waiver of procedures; authorized actions. During a state of emergency, the procedures and formalities otherwise required of the city by law may be waived by the city manager, upon a finding that said action is necessary to respond to conditions created by the disaster; in such case, he/she may authorize actions pertaining to the following as necessary: 
1.  Performing public work and taking whatever action is necessary to ensure the health, safety, and welfare of the community; 
2.  Entering into contracts; 
3.  Suspending bid provisions for a period not to exceed six (6) months from the declaration of the emergency; 
4.  Employment of permanent and temporary workers; 
5.  Utilization of volunteer workers; 
6.  Rental of equipment; 
7.  Acquisition and distribution of supplies, materials, and facilities; 
8.  Additional appropriation and expenditure of funds as needed for the emergency; 
9.  Implementing emergency personnel policies; 
10.  Activating and/or executing the statewide mutual-aid system and/or interlocal agreements; 
11.  Determining a threat to public health and safety that may result from the generation of widespread debris throughout the city, that such debris constitutes a hazardous environment for all modes of movement and transportation of the residents as well as emergency aid and relief services, endangerment to all properties in the city, an environment conducive to breeding disease and vermin, and greatly increased risk of fire, and that it is in the public interest to collect and remove disaster debris from all property within the city, whether publicly-owned lands, privately-owned lands, both public and private roads and easements, including lands and roads located within any private, gated community to eliminate an immediate threat of additional damage to improved property and to promote economic recovery of the community at large and the health and safety of the community at large; 
12.  Authorize the city or its contracted agent right of access to private roads and easements and/or gated communities as needed by emergency vehicles such as, but not limited to, police, fire, medical care, debris removal, utility repairs, and sanitation to alleviate immediate threats to public health and safety; 
13.  Authorize the removal of debris and wreckage resulting from a major disaster from all property whether public lands, public or private roads, or gated communities for a safe and sanitary living or functioning condition and to ensure proper access by public safety vehicles; 
14.  Authorize the removal of derelict vessels pursuant to current state statutes and in conjunction with the state fish and wildlife conservation commission; 
15.  Authorize the removal of abandoned vehicles pursuant to current state statutes and in conjunction with law enforcement of the city, county, and state; and 
16.  Close or restrict access to public facilities. 
In the case of any actions of the city manager, as authorized in this subsection, the contracts authorized shall not exceed the period of the state of local emergency or thirty (30) days, whichever is less. Any such extension of said contracts shall only be made after a vote of the city commission. All such contracts executed shall be subject to this limitation. All contracts executed by the city manager pursuant to this authority shall be placed on file with the city clerk and the city manager shall report the execution of said contracts, including the vendor's name, the services or material provided, and the cost, as soon as practicable to the city commission. 
(e)  Emergency response costs. Any expenditure made in conjunction with emergency activities, including mutual aid agreements and interlocal agreements, shall be deemed conclusively to be for the direct protection and benefit of the inhabitants and property of the city. 
(f)  City responsibility for debris removal from private rights-of-way. If the property owner has executed an agreement with the city in accordance with section 2-101(g) of the City Code granting the city access to private property for debris removal purposes, the city shall be responsible for the removal of disaster-generated debris from private rights-of-way adjacent to residential property when the disaster-generated debris is determined by the city manager, in the city manager's sole discretion in accordance with this section, (i) to pose an immediate threat to the health, safety and welfare of the public in the area, (ii) to pose an immediate threat of significant damage to surrounding improved property within the city, or (iii) to require removal to provide an economic benefit to the community as a whole. 
    In order to determine that there is such an immediate threat or circumstance sufficient to warrant removal of disaster-generated debris from private rights-of-way adjacent to residential property within the city, the city manager shall first consider the factors in this subsection and make a written finding as to whether the presence and/or imminent development of any of the dangers or aggravating factors below exists: 
(1)  There is a significant likelihood that rescue vehicles will be significantly hindered from rendering emergency services to property should the debris be allowed to remain in place absent city removal; or 
(2)  The type of disaster-generated debris is such that it may reasonably cause disease, illness, or sickness which could injure or adversely affect the health, safety, or general welfare of those residing and working in the area if it is allowed to remain; or 
(3)  The clearing is necessary to effectuate orderly and expeditious restoration of citywide utility services including, but not limited to, power, water, sewer, and telephone; or 
(4)  The disaster-generated debris is determined to be dangerous or hazardous to persons or property; or 
(5)  The disaster-generated debris prevents garbage collection thereby creating a public health hazard; or 
(6)  The disaster-generated debris contains contaminants which have a reasonable likelihood of leaching into the soil and/or aquifer of the city; or 
(7)  The disaster-generated debris has a substantial negative impact in preventing or adversely affecting emergency repairs to buildings and/or property; or 
(8)  The disaster-generated debris presents a reasonable danger of being transported by wind and/or water into the surrounding areas of the city and thereby increasing the cost of recovery and removal; or 
(9)  The disaster-generated debris poses a significant likelihood of producing mold which would be injurious to public health; or 
(10)  The presence of the disaster-generated debris significantly adversely impacts the city's recovery efforts; or 
(11)  The disaster-generated debris significantly interferes with drainage or water runoff, so as to be a significant hazard in the event of significant rainfall; or 
(12)  The sheer volume of the disaster-generated debris is such that it is impractical and unreasonable to remove in an orderly and efficient manner absent action by the city; or 
(13)  The type, extent and nature of the disaster-generated debris is such that it would cause much greater damage if the debris was not removed immediately; or 
(14)  If the clearance of the disaster-generated debris will aid the city's recovery operations or aid the health, safety, or welfare of the residents of the city. 
(g)  Hold harmless agreement. Notwithstanding any other provision of this section, the city shall not have responsibility to enter and remove event-generated debris from private property until it has obtained the right to enter said property by the private property owner. 
(1)  Prior to the city, or the city's authorized agent, entering private rights-of-way or other private property to clear and/or remove disaster-generated debris, the private property owner shall execute an agreement for disaster debris removal with the city agreeing to indemnify, defend and hold the federal government, the State of Florida, and the city, and their respective agencies, employees, officers and agents, harmless for claims arising from the city's removal of disaster-generated debris. 
(2)  The agreement for disaster debris removal shall also include the ability for the city or private property owner to terminate the agreement for convenience upon sixty (60) days' written notice, and such other terms that are acceptable to the city manager and approved as to form and legal sufficiency by the city attorney. The city manager or designee is authorized to execute the disaster debris removal agreements on behalf of the city. 
(h)  Disaster-generated debris from residential property. 
(1)  Responsibility. Residential property owners are responsible for the collection and removal of disaster-generated debris from their property, except to the extent the city is responsible for removal of disaster-generated debris from private rights-of-way as provided in section 2-101(f) above. 
(2)  Piling requirement. As provided in this section, the city may remove disaster-generated debris collected from residential property. Residential property owners desiring the city to remove disaster-generated debris shall collect and locate in piles all disaster-generated debris as required by this section before the city's last pass for removal of disaster-generated debris. Disaster-generated debris piles put out for removal after the city makes its last pass will not be removed by the city. 
(3)  Segregation requirement. Residential property owners must segregate structural debris piles from vegetative debris piles, and these piles must be segregated from household waste. Household waste shall be bagged and placed in garbage cans. Structural debris and vegetative debris shall not be bagged, except that loose vegetative debris may be placed in large plastic bags. 
(4)  Placement of piles. Residential property owners shall place disaster debris piles: 
a.  In front of their residence in the swale area immediately adjacent to the edge of the public or private roadway; and 
b.  In such a manner as to allow ingress and egress to all residential properties. Residential property owners may combine their several piles of segregated disaster-generated debris into larger piles to accomplish this requirement. 
(5)  Damage to sidewalks or mailboxes. The city and its agents shall not be responsible for damage to sidewalks or mailboxes when disaster-generated debris is placed on or adjacent thereto. 
(6)  City determination. If the city determines that: 
a.  The residential property owner's structural debris, vegetative debris and/or household waste is commingled, or has not been collected in accordance with this section, the residential property owner shall have forty-eight (48) hours to properly segregate the disaster-generated debris. If the residential property owner fails to properly segregate his or her disaster-generated within forty-eight (48) hours, then the residential property owner is required to remove and dispose of the disaster-generated debris at his or her expense; or 
b.  Any disaster-generated debris from nonresidential property, including community property, has been commingled with the disaster-generated debris of a residential property owner, then the city will not remove the disaster-generated debris and the residential property owner is required to remove the disaster-generated debris piles at his or her expense. 
(i)  Disaster-generated debris from nonresidential property. 
(1)  Commingling. The city will not remove disaster-generated debris that has come from or been commingled with disaster-generated debris from: 
a.  Nonresidential property; 
b.  Landscaped medians or cul-de-sacs in communities with private rights-of-way; or 
c.  Privately owned parks or other privately owned properties that are not residential. 
(2)  Disposal of all disaster-generated debris. Nonresidential property owners shall collect, reduce, remove and otherwise dispose of all disaster-generated debris on their property within sixty (60) days of the end of the disaster. 
(3)  Prohibition of commingling. Nonresidential property owners shall not: 
a.  Move disaster-generated debris from their property to residential property; or 
b.  Collect their disaster-generated debris and commingle it with a residential property owner's disaster-generated debris piles. 
(4)  Tub grinding operations. Tub grinding operations or any other operation to reduce disaster debris from nonresidential property must be conducted at least two hundred (200) feet away from residential property. 
(Ord. No. 2012-01, § 2(2-101), 2-1-2012; Ord. No. 2017-08, § 2, 8-16-2017) 
Secs. 2-102-2-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - EMPLOYEE BENEFITS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-111-2-121. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OLD AGE AND SURVIVORS' INSURANCE[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Social security, F.S. Ch. 650. 

Sec. 2-122. - Policy and purpose. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend effective as of October 1, 1976, to the employees and officials thereof, not excluded by law, nor excepted herein, the benefits of the system of Old Age and Survivors' Insurance as authorized by the Federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, and by Chapter 650, Florida Statutes, as amended and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined in Section 650.02, Florida Statutes, performed in the employ of the city by employees and officials thereof, except service in any class or classes of elective positions, service in any class of part-time positions, and service in any class of positions, the compensation for which is on a fee basis. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 1, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-123. - Exclusions. 
    There is hereby excluded from this division any authority to include in any agreement entered into under section 2-124 hereof any service, position, employee, or official now covered by or eligible to be covered by an existing retirement system. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 2, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-124. - Agreements. 
(a)  The mayor is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the state agency for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of Old Age and Survivors' Insurance to the employees and officials of this city as provided in sections 2-122 and 2-123 hereof. 
(b)  The agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary and proper, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed on and after October 1, 1976. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 3, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-125. - Withholding of contributions. 
    Withholdings from salaries, wages, or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose provided in section 2-122 hereof are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by the laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 4, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-126. - Appropriation. 
    There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from payroll, such amounts, at such times, as may be required to pay promptly the contributions and assessments required of the city as employer by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 5, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-127. - Records and reports. 
    The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the regulations of the state agency. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 6, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-128. - Adoption. 
    The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges, and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended, for and on behalf of all officers and employees of its departments and agencies to be covered under the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 39, § 7, 11-17-1976) 
Sec. 2-129. - Custodian and reporting agent. 
(a)  The city clerk of the city is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees and of the appropriated funds for the contribution of the city. 
(b)  The city clerk of the city is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this division. 
Secs. 2-130-2-135. - Reserved.

ARTICLE VII. - PROCUREMENT CODE[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2007, repealed and replaced former Art. VII, §§ 2-141-2-146, and enacted a new Art. VII as set out herein. The former Art. VII pertained to similar subject matter. For complete derivation see the Code Comparative Table at the end of this volume. 
Ord. No. 2018-001, adopted Mar. 7, 2018, changed the title of art. VII from Finance Purchasing Guidelines to Procurement Code. 

Sec. 2-141. - Purpose; generally. 
    The purpose of these purchasing regulations is to: 
(a)  Provide a uniform means of acquiring goods and services in a manner which protects the interests of taxpayers; 
(b)  Ensures that qualified vendors have access to the municipal market on a fair and equitable basis; 
(c)  Applies to all purchases of the city irrespective of the source of funding; 
(d)  Provides guidelines to user departments. 
    The finance department shall serve as the purchasing gateway to provide assistance and technical expertise in purchasing procedures, and to ascertain that user departments understand and comply with established budgetary, purchasing and accounting procedures for overall internal control. No city employee shall order goods or services without the required authorization, funding and purchasing/finance documents. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1, 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Sec. 2-141.1. - Delegated authority. 
    The city manager shall appoint the purchasing director or designee as the authority to implement the provisions of this article. The purchasing director or designee shall be responsible for the procurement of goods and services governed by this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Sec. 2-141.2. - Micro purchases less than two thousand five hundred dollars. 
    Department heads have authorization to purchase goods and services which are less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00), for a single purchase, subject to a valid, current appropriation for the item(s) to be purchased. Payment for the goods and services shall be made using a purchase order, procurement card or a check request form, unless the item is a capital asset. All purchases of capital assets require a purchase order. The procurement requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a micro purchase. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1(2-141.1), 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A) 3-7-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-001, adopted Mar. 7, 2018, added provisions to be designated § 2-141.1, and renumbered §§ 2-141.1-2-141.6 as §§ 2-141.2-2-142.7. 
Sec. 2-141.3. - Small purchases of two thousand five hundred dollars and less than five thousand dollars. 
    In addition to the requirements in section 2-141.2, purchases of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) and less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) must have sought minimum of three (3) verbal quotes and written authorization to the purchasing director or designee in the form of a purchase requisition. Documentation of the phone number and the name of the person who gave the quote, or a memorandum that a quote was sought, must be provided with the purchase requisition. The procurement requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a small purchase. Award shall be made to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1(2-141.2), 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2015-06, § 1, 5-20-2015; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 2-141.2. 
Sec. 2-141.4. - Small purchases of five thousand dollars and less than twenty-five thousand dollars. 
    In addition to the requirements in section 2-141.2, purchases of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) and less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) must have sought three (3) written quotes and written authorization to the purchasing director or designee in the form of a purchase requisition. Written quotes or evidence that a quote was sought must be provided with the purchase requisition. The procurement requirements shall not be artificially divided so as to constitute a small purchase. Award shall be made to the lowest responsive and responsible bidder. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1(2-141.3), 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2015-06, § 2, 5-20-2015; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note following § 2-141.2. 
Sec. 2-141.5. - Purchases above twenty-five thousand dollars or more. 
    Purchases of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) or more require a competitive solicitation process, and city commission approval, except for purchases defined in exempt purchases, section 2-143.9, and emergency purchases, section 2-144. Purchase requisition must be approved prior to ordering. Contracts covering multiple years shall be considered as above twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) if the annual contract amount multiplied by the number of years of the contract term exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). 
    Procurement of goods or services from the same vendor exceeding the aggregate sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) shall not be permitted during the course of any fiscal year, unless the acquisition is first approved by the city commission. This subsection shall not apply to continuing contracts with prior approval by the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1(2-141.4), 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note following § 2-141.2. 
Sec. 2-141.6. - Professional engineering and architectural services. 
    Where required by law, professional services subject to shall be procured in accordance with the Consultants' Competitive Negotiations Act (CCNA) as provided for in F.S. § 287.055, and section 2-146 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1(2-141.5), 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note following § 2-141.2. 
Sec. 2-141.7. - Projects coordinated with other governmental entities. 
    The competitive procedures set forth in sections 2-141.2 through 2-141.6 shall not be required where the city is undertaking a project in conjunction with another governmental entity or undertaking a project or procuring materials on city property or the property of another governmental entity. In such cases, by motion, the city commission may decide to award a contract without the necessity of a competitive bid where the following circumstances exist: 
(a)  The project is in coordination with another governmental entity; 
(b)  The project is on property owned by the city or owned by another governmental entity; 
(c)  The other governmental entity which is participating in the project recommends a particular contractor or supplier based upon prior direct experience with that contractor or the contractor or supplier has recently provided a similar service or product or in the case of design services, a design which is substantially similar to that provided to the governmental entity with whom the city is cooperating on a joint project; 
(d)  The total cost of the improvements to the city is less than three million dollars ($3,000,000.00); and 
(e)  The city commission finds that the contract is in the best interests of the city, is competitively priced, and will further intergovernmental cooperation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1(2-141.6), 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Editor's note- See editor's note following § 2-141.2. 
Sec. 2-142. - Competitive solicitations. 
    All purchases and contractual services in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), except as otherwise specified herein, shall be purchased upon approval of the city commission only after a competitive bid, competitive proposal or a request for qualification process is employed based upon the discretion of the purchasing director or designee. 
(a)  Competitive bids. Competitive bids shall be used where the purchasing director or designee determines in his/her sole discretion, that the services to be purchased are generally comparable from all sources and where price is the most significant factor in the award of the bid; contracts for most goods or construction services are typically let in this fashion. The bid specifications may set forth various criteria regarding experience, qualifications, and other matters to ensure that the bids being considered are from bidders who are qualified to provide the products or services. 
(b)  Request for proposals (RFP). Request for proposals shall be used where the purchasing director or designee determines in his/her sole discretion, that besides price, there will be a special need to consider, in greater depth, the ability of the proposer to provide the goods or services or the nature of the goods or services or where there may be a need for discretion or creativity in the manner in which the goods or services are provided. The purchasing director or designee may waive minor irregularities in the competitive solicitation process. The request for proposals shall set forth the evaluation criteria for evaluating and ranking the responsive and responsible firms. RFPs shall be procured in accordance with section 2-143.8.1 of this Code. 
(c)  Request for qualifications (RFQ) (non CCNA). Request for qualifications shall be used where the purchasing director or designee determines in his/her sole discretion, that price is not the basis for the award, but the qualifications of the various proposers and their ability to perform the proposed project. The request for qualifications shall set forth the standards by which the contract shall be awarded. The purchasing director or designee may waive minor irregularities in the competitive solicitation process. RFQs shall be procured in accordance with section 2-143.8.2 of this Code. 
(d)  Request for information (RFI). Request for information shall be used where the purchasing director or designee determines in his/her sole discretion, that it is necessary to assess the market, feasibility of a proposed project, service or commodity, or when vendor input to specifications or a scope of work would result in a more competitive and fair competitive solicitation process a request for information (RFI) may be issued requesting submission of unpriced offers, products or scopes of services which may be followed by subsequent competitive solicitation that is not limited to those firms who responded to the RFI. 
(Ord. No. 2007-22, § 1(exh. A), 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2009-22, § 1, 7-1-2009; Ord. No. 2012-07, § 1, 4-18-2012; Ord. No. 2015-03, § 1, 3-18-2015; Ord. No. 2018-001, § 1(exh. A), 3-7-2018) 
Sec. 2-142.1. - Exemption from public records and public meeting requirements. 
(1)  Responses received by the city pursuant to a competitive solicitation are exempt from the Public Records Law (F.S. § 119.07) until such time as the city provides notice of an intended decision or within thirty (30) days after opening the bids, proposals or final replies, whichever is earlier, unless it is competitive solicitation for construction or repairs on a public building or public work, in which case the responses shall be opened in compliance with F.S. § 286.011, the name of each bidder and the price submitted in the bid shall be announced, and the name of each bidder and the price submitted in the bid shall be made available upon request. 
(2)  For the purposes of this subsection "proposer" shall mean a person or company which responds to a request for proposals or a request for qualifications. 
(3)  Any portion of a meeting at which a negotiation with a proposer is conducted pursuant to a competitive solicitation, at which a proposer makes an oral presentation or answers questions as part of the competitive solicitation process shall be exempt from the Sunshine Law in accordance with F.S. § 286.0113. 
(4)  Any portion of an evaluation committee meeting at which negotiation strategies are discussed by the evaluation committee shall be exempt from the Sunshine Law in accordance with F.S. § 286.0113. 
(5)  A complete recording shall be made of any portion of an exempt meeting. No portion of the exempt meeting may be held off the record. 
(6)  The recording of. and any records presented at the exempt meeting are exempt from the Public Records Law (F.S. § 119.07) until such time as the city provides notice of an intended decision or until thirty (30) days after opening the proposals whichever occurs earlier. 
(7)  If the city rejects all competitive solicitations and concurrently provides notice of its intent to reissue a competitive solicitation, rejected bids, proposals or replies remain exempt from the Public Records Law (F.S. § 119.07) until such time as the city provides notice of an intended decision concerning the reissued competitive solicitation or until the city withdraws the reissued competitive solicitation. A bid, proposal or reply is not exempt for longer than twelve (12) months after the initial city notice rejecting all bids, proposals or replies. The recording and any records presented at an exempt meeting remain exempt from the Public Records Law (F.S. § 119.07) until such time as the city provides notice of an intended decision concerning the reissued competitive solicitation or until the city withdraws the reissued competitive solicitation. A recording and any records presented at an exempt meeting are not exempt for longer than twelve (12) months after the initial city notice rejecting all proposals. 
(8)  The public notice of the evaluation committee meeting shall state that the portion of the meeting at which the proposer makes a presentation or answers questions and the portion of the meeting at which the evaluation committee discusses negotiation strategies are exempt from the Sunshine Law in accordance with F.S. § 286.0113. 
(Ord. No. 2017-04, § 1, 5-17-2017) 
Sec. 2-142.2. - Cone of silence. 
(1)  Prohibited communication. Except as set forth in subsection (4), during the course of a competitive solicitation, a cone of silence shall be in effect between:
