(k)  Alarm user means any person, business, firm, partnership, corporation, association, organization, company or other entity deemed by the city to be an alarm user that possesses and/or uses and/or operates an alarm system within the city limits. 
(l)  Excessive false alarms means a third or subsequent false alarm occurring during the calendar year, which was not caused by extreme weather conditions. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2009-16E, § 2, 4-15-2009) 
Sec. 11-61. - False alarm fees. 
(a)  False alarms: 
(1)  First three false alarms free of charge 
(2)  Fourth false alarm ..... $100.00 
(3)  Fifth and above false alarms ..... 250.00 
(b)  Failure to pay within thirty (30) days, service fee each ..... 35.00 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-62. - Prohibition of certain telephone alarm devices. 
(a)  Except for telephone alarm devices utilized by governmental units or agencies, it is unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or association to install, maintain, own, possess, operate or use any telephone alarm device regulated or programmed to make connection with: 
(1)  Any telephone or telephone line installed in any facility of any law enforcement office; 
(2)  Any telephone or telephone line installed in any facility as part of the 911 system. 
(b)  Telephone alarm devices are permitted when not connected directly to a law enforcement office or any facility as part of the 911 system, but they are subject to all other provisions of this article. 
(c)  Any alarm system which automatically telephones a law enforcement agency over telephone lines exclusively used by the public or request emergency services or information. 
(d)  Any alarm systems which do not have an auxiliary power supply which activates in the event of power failure or electrical outage. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-63. - Removal of unlawful systems. 
    The law enforcement officer, when there is probable cause to believe that there has been a violation of section 11-62(a)(1) or (2) of this article, shall order the owner, operator or lessee to disconnect and cease operation of the system within seventy-two (72) hours of receipt of the order. Notice shall be by personal service. If personal service cannot be made, notice shall be by certified mail, return receipt requested. Any telephone alarm device installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall have been removed within thirty (30) days of such date. It shall be unlawful for any person as defined in this article to fail to comply with the provisions of the article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-64. - Deactivation of audible alarms within thirty minutes. 
    It is unlawful to maintain any alarm system or audible alarm that does not deactivate within thirty (30) minutes of its activation. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-65. - Intentional activation of alarms prohibited if no emergency exists. 
    It is unlawful for any person to intentionally activate any alarm system or audible alarm except in the event of an actual or attempted felony, misdemeanor, fire or medical emergency or to periodically test the alarm equipment after giving advance notice to the law enforcement officer. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-66. - False alarms. 
    For a law enforcement agency, fire department, or emergency medical personnel response to an incident of a false alarm as the result of the activation of any alarm system or audible alarm, the following fees and procedures shall apply: 
(1)  For a response to premises at which no other false alarm has occurred within the preceding six (6) months, no fee shall be charged; but the person having or maintaining the alarm system or audible alarm shall, within three (3) working days after notice to do so, complete a written report to the law enforcement officer on forms prescribed by the law enforcement officer, setting forth the cause of the false alarm if known; the corrective action taken; whether the alarm system has been inspected by a licensed alarm service company and such other information as the law enforcement officer may reasonably require to determine the cause of such false alarm and the necessary corrective action. 
(2)  No fee for a second or third response to premises within six (6) months after a first response shall be charged; the law enforcement officer shall be authorized to cause the alarm system at the premises to be inspected during reasonable hours by an independent alarm service company or a duly authorized agent of the law enforcement office with a written report furnished to the law enforcement officer by the inspector within seventy-two (72) hours. Written notice shall be either issued to an adult occupant of the residence, structure or building or if no such person is available shall be left in a prominent place at the residence, structure or building. The law enforcement officer shall prescribe necessary corrective action, and shall give notice to the person having or maintaining the alarm system of the conditions and requirements of this article. All costs of such inspections, including the alarm service company's fee, shall be paid by the person who owns or maintains the alarm system or audible alarm, as the case may be. 
(3)  For a fourth response to premises by city's law enforcement agency, fire department, or emergency medical personnel within twelve (12) months after a third response (as described in subsection (2) above), and for all succeeding responses within six (6) months of the most recent response, a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be charged, and if the fourth false alarm of any succeeding false alarm has resulted from the failure to take any corrective action prescribed by the law enforcement officer, the law enforcement officer may serve a written notice upon the person owning or maintaining such audible alarm or alarm system ordering the disconnection of such alarm system or audible alarm. It shall be unlawful for the person owning or maintaining such alarm system or audible alarm to fail to disconnect such alarm system upon order to the law enforcement officer, and it shall further be unlawful to reconnect said alarm system or audible alarm until the prescribed corrective action has been taken; provided, however, that no alarm system or audible alarm shall be disconnected where such alarm system or audible alarm is situated in any premises required by law to have such alarm system or audible alarm in operation. 
(4)  An alarm that has been ordered by the law enforcement officer to be disconnected may be reconnected upon satisfactory proof submitted to the law enforcement officer that the prescribed corrective action has been taken. 
(5)  Notice of a false alarm shall be by personal service. If personal service cannot be made, notice shall be by registered mail, return receipt requested or posted on the property. The city's law enforcement agency, fire department and emergency medical personnel shall provide the city with a copy of each false alarm notice issued. Notice shall be in essentially the following form: 
"You are hereby notified that you have violated Parkland Code of Ordinances, Chapter 11, Article VI, which prohibits certain false alarms. This is your ___________ violation of the ordinance. Previous violations occurred on ___________ (dates) ___________. The most recent violation occurred on ___________ (date) ___________, at ___________ (address) ___________, at ___________ (time)." 
"Within three (3) days of receipt of this notice you are required to submit a written report setting forth the cause of the false alarm if known, the corrective action taken, and whether the alarm system has been inspected by an alarm service company." 
"As this is the ___________ false alarm over a ___________ month period, you are (not) subject to a fine of one hundred dollars ($100.00)." 
"Furthermore, if there has been more than one (1) false alarm within the past six (6) months, your alarm system is subject to inspection at your expense by an independent alarm service company or by this department." 
"Violations of the terms of the Parkland Code of Ordinances, Chapter 11, Article VI, may cause your alarm system to be disconnected, and may subject you to a fine, incarceration or both." 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-67. - Exception for new installations. 
    All newly installed alarm systems shall be exempt from the regulations of section 11-66 above, in-order to allow alarm installers and users to adjust the system. New installations shall be subject to the regulations of section 11-66 above, thirty (30) days after installation is complete. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-68. - Penalties. 
    Violation of the provisions and prohibitions of this article shall constitute an offense and violation of a city ordinance. Any person who is convicted of a violation by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail not to exceed sixty (60) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2007-19, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
ARTICLE VII. - PARK REGULATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to instructions by the city, Ord. No. 89-27, §§ 1-9, adopted Dec. 6, 1989, has been codified herein as Art. VII, §§ 11-69-11-77. 
Cross reference- Parks and Recreation Advisory Board, § 2-46 et seq. 

Sec. 11-69. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words have the meanings indicated: 
    City parks: All the land surface, the air space above and all subsequent subjacent materials situated in the city acquired by or under the jurisdiction of the parks and recreation department which may be acquired or come under its jurisdiction, and all property upon which is located the city hall, city public works building, city public safety building, and any other city municipal building. Wherever here the words "park" or "parks" may be used, reference is made to such city land areas as described herein. 
    Department: The department of parks and recreation. 
    Drone: An unmanned vehicle, aircraft or ship that can navigate autonomously, without human control or beyond line of sight. 
    Nuisance: Conduct which, without direct physical invasion of person, annoys or impairs the quiet and comfortable enjoyment of others. 
    Park roads: All surfaced areas, either paved or unpaved, designated for vehicular traffic and passing through any legally defined park area or part thereof. All other trafficways not designated for vehicular traffic are classified as work trails, bridle trails or simply trails or paths. 
    Parking area: Any designated part of any park road, drive or special area contiguous thereto set apart for the standing or stationing of any vehicles. 
    Person: Any individual regardless of age or sex; or any corporation, company, association, firm, copartnership, club or society or any association of persons; or any agent or employee thereof. 
    Vehicle: Any wheeled conveyance (except a baby carriage or invalid wheelchair) for the transportation of persons or materials whether: 
(1)  Powered or drawn by motor as an automobile, truck, motorcycle or scooter; or 
(2)  Animal-drawn as a carriage, wagon or cart; or 
(3)  Any self-propelled bicycle or tricycle; or 
(4)  Any trailer in tow of any size, kind or description. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 1, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 1, 8-7-1991; Ord. No. 2009-16E, § 2, 4-15-2009; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 2, 3-2-2016) 
Sec. 11-70. - Traffic in parks. 
    The restrictions and regulations contained herein shall apply to all city parks as follows: 
(a)  State law. All applicable provisions of laws and rules regulating the equipment and operation of motor vehicles on Florida highways will be strictly enforced in the parks, together with such rules provided in this article. 
(b)  Directions of traffic. All traffic officers and designated park employees are authorized and instructed to direct traffic whenever and whenever needed in the parks and on the highways, streets or roads immediately adjacent thereto in accordance with the provisions of this article and such supplementary rules as may be issued by the division or other state agency. No person shall fail to comply with any lawful order, signal or direction of such officer or employee. All persons shall observe carefully all traffic signs indicating speed, direction, caution, stopping or parking and all others posted for proper control and to safeguard life and property. 
(c)  Speed of vehicles in parks. No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed exceeding ten (10) miles per hour. 
(d)  Restriction to roads. No person shall drive any motorized vehicle on any area except park roads or parking areas or such other areas as are designated as temporary parking areas. 
(e)  Parking. 
(1)  All motor cars shall be parked only in established and indicated parking areas or in such other areas and at such times as may be designated. 
(2)  Full parking on roads or driveways is forbidden at all times except in an emergency. 
(3)  No person shall park or station any vehicle in any zone designated and marked no parking or otherwise marked for restricted use except briefly for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers or freight. 
(4)  No person shall make nonemergency repairs, perform routine maintenance or wash any vehicle in any city park or recreation area. 
(5)  No vehicles are permitted to remain in a parking area after closing hours. Any vehicle parked continuously in the park for in excess of twenty-four (24) hours will be towed at the owner's expense. 
(f)  Bicycles. Bicycles may be ridden on any designated roads or trails. When riding vehicular roads, they must observe all safety rules and regulations as constituted by state law. Bicyclists shall, when riding or parking their bikes, respect the safety and security of other park users. 
(g)  [Prohibited areas.] All wheeled vehicles are prohibited from all tennis and basketball courts, but may be ridden on any designated road or trail. 
(h)  [Penalty.] The penalty for violation of this section shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each incident. 
(i)  [Enforcement.] Violations of this section may be enforced by issuance of a citation as provided in chapter 20 of this Code or by any other means permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 2, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 2, 8-7-1991; Ord. No. 97-28, § 1, 1-7-1998; Ord. No. 2004-04, §§ 2-4, 10-20-2004) 
Sec. 11-71. - Park property. 
    The restrictions and regulations contained herein shall apply to all city parks as follows: 
(a)  Buildings and other property. No person shall willfully mark, deface or injure in any way or displace, remove or tamper with any park buildings, bridges, tables, benches, fireplaces, railings, paving or paving material, waterlines or public utilities or parts or appurtenances thereof, park signs, notices or placards, whether temporary or permanent, monuments, stakes, posts or other boundary markers or other structures or equipment, facilities or park property or appurtenances whatsoever, either real or personal. 
(b)  Trees, shrubbery, lawns, etc. Trees, shrubbery, lawns, etc., are property assets of the park; and no person shall cut, carve or injure the bark or break off limbs or branches or mutilate in any way or pick the flowers or seeds of any tree or plant; nor shall any person dig in or otherwise disturb grass areas or in any other way injure or impair the natural beauty or usefulness of any area; nor shall he pile debris or material of any kind on or about any tree or plat or attach any rope, wire or other contrivance thereto whether temporary or permanent in character or use. 
(c)  Wild animals, birds, etc. No person shall molest, harm, frighten, kill, trap, hunt, chase, capture, shoot or throw missiles at any mammal, bird, reptile or amphibian; nor shall he remove or have in his possession the young of any wild animal or the eggs, nests or young of any reptile or bird. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 3, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 3, 8-7-1991) 
Sec. 11-72. - Recreational activities and facilities. 
    The restrictions and regulations contained herein shall apply to all city parks as follows: 
(a)  Tents. No person shall erect, maintain, use or occupy in any area any tent, canopy, shelter or structure of any kind within a city park, with the exception of a temporary sun-shade canopy. 
(1)  Temporary sun-shade canopies shall be defined as not exceeding ten (10) feet by ten (10) feet in size, open sided, containing no hanging items and must be securely fashioned to the ground through the use of tent stakes in each leg. 
(2)  No person shall erect a temporary sun-shade canopy earlier than thirty (30) minutes prior to scheduled activity start times and must be removed within thirty (30) minutes following the activity. 
(3)  Placement of temporary sun-shade canopies is limited to the sidelines of athletic fields during officially scheduled city-recognized events. 
(4)  Placement of temporary sun-shade canopies may not impede the visibility of other spectators as determined by the leisure services director or his/her designee. 
(5)  Temporary sun-shade canopies shall not be attached to another temporary sun-shade canopy and shall not placed next to permanent or temporary structures. 
(b)  Fires. 
(1)  No person shall start or maintain any outdoor fire except in designated areas. Fires shall be limited to cooking on picnic grills. No ground fires [shall be] permitted. 
(2)  Cooking fires shall be started and maintained only in a stove, fireplace or barbecue pit maintained by the parks department. Fuels used in cooking fires shall not produce any noxious fumes or smoke. 
(3)  No person starting or maintaining any fire in a park shall leave the area without first extinguishing the fire. 
(4)  Special events cooking permits may be obtained from the city. 
(c)  Camping. No person shall set up tents, shacks or any other temporary shelter or bring in any recreational vehicle for the purpose of camping. Camping shall be prohibited in city parks. 
(d)  Horseback riding. Horses are not permitted on any ballfield or play area of a park. Horses shall not go unattended. 
(e)  Photography. No person shall take still or motion pictures for commercial purposes, involving the use of special settings or structures or the performance of a cast or persons, either amateur or professional, without first obtaining written permission from the city commission or its designee. Otherwise, there shall be no restriction on photographic activities. 
(f)  Permits. The city commission or its designee may, upon written application, grant specific use permits for special uses when, in the opinion of the city commission, special consideration is warranted. 
(g)  Fees and charges. The city commission may determine and fix by resolution such fees and charges for services and activities made available in city parks. 
(h)  Swimming. No person in a park shall swim or bathe in any waterway that is in or adjacent to any park. 
(i)  Fishing. No person shall engage in fishing at any location where such activity is prohibited unless such activity has been approved via a special events permit. 
(j)  Launching of boats, jet skis, radio-controlled or other water vehicles from any city property. It shall be illegal and a violation of this section for any person to launch or propel from any city property, or the shoreline adjacent to any city property, a boat, a jet ski or any other similar type water vehicle into the waters adjacent. 
(k)  Playground rules. Individuals shall adhere to all posted playground rules. 
(l)  Remote controlled vehicles or drones. Remote controlled vehicles or drones are not permitted within any city park. 
(m)  Golf. No person shall strike a golf ball within any city park unless such activity is part of a city-authorized program. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 4, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 4, 8-7-1991; Ord. No. 97-28, § 2, 1-7-1998; Ord. No. 2007-06, § 1, 4-18-2007; Ord. No. 2009-16B, § 2, 4-15-2009; Ord. No. 2010-12, § 2, 7-7-2010; Ord. No. 2016-01, § 2, 3-2-2016) 
Sec. 11-73. - Hours of operation. 
    The restrictions and regulations contained herein shall apply to all city parks as follows: Parks will be open as posted, including hours of operation. Any section or part of any park may be declared closed to the public at any time or limited to certain users or times as public interest demands or safety and security indicates at the discretion of the parks. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 5, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 5, 8-7-1991) 
Sec. 11-74. - Nuisances. 
    The restrictions and regulations contained herein shall apply to all city parks as follows: 
(a)  Intoxicating beverages. Drinking, possession of or bringing alcoholic beverages into any city park is prohibited except during a special event conducted and authorized by the city. 
(b)  Fireworks and explosives. Possessing, exploding, discharging or burning within or bringing into any park area any fireworks or other potentially dangerous inflammable material, including model rockets, is prohibited except during a special event conducted and authorized by the city. 
(c)  Domestic animals. Domestic animals shall be excluded from all city parks except the Parkland Equestrian Center at Temple Park. Domestic animals may run freely (provided they are under human control) at the Parkland Equestrian Center at Temple Park except during special events. 
(d)  Public nuisance and disorderly conduct. Whoever commits such acts as are of a nature to corrupt the public morals or outrage the sense of public decency or affect the peace and quiet of persons who may witness them or engages in brawling or fighting or engages in such conduct as to constitute a hazard to the health, safety or welfare of other park visitors shall, upon due notice of violation, be classed as a trespasser and ordered to leave the park by any authorized city representative. 
(e)  City buildings or pavilion. No hoofed animals shall be permitted in or upon city buildings or the pavilion located at the Parkland Equestrian Center at Temple Park. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 6, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 6, 8-7-1991; Ord. No. 92-24, § 1, 8-5-1992; Ord. No. 95-11, § 1, 11-1-1995; Ord. No. 2006-37, § 1, 9-6-2006; Ord. No. 2009-16C, § 2, 4-15-2009; Ord. No. 2011-29, § 3, 10-5-2011) 
Sec. 11-75. - Merchandising, advertising and signs. 
    The restrictions and regulations contained herein shall apply to all city parks as follows: 
(a)  Vending, peddling, etc. No person shall expose or offer for sale any article or thing, or food or drink; nor shall he station or place any stand, cart or vehicle for the transportation, sale or display of any such article, merchandise, food or drink; nor shall he sell any such article, merchandise, food or drink within the limits of any city park or any public right-of-way or public property; provided that such sale shall be permitted for authorized city concessionaires, operating pursuant to a contract with the city, or by special permit issued by the city commission or the city manager, where a determination is made that such sale is in the best interests of the public and is related to a special event or city function. 
(b)  Advertising and publicity. All advertising or publicity posted or announced in or on park property must be approved by the city commission or its designee. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 7, 12-6-1989; Ord. No. 91-25, § 7, 8-7-1991; Ord. No. 97-23, § 1, 12-3-1997) 
Sec. 11-76. - Variance. 
    The city commission grants a variance from the provisions of this article in the interests of the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 8, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 11-77. - Enforcement and penalties. 
    This article may be enforced by the public safety department. Any person, firm or entity who shall violate any of the regulations, restrictions, limitations and provisions contained in this article shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 89-27, § 9, 12-6-1989) 
Sec. 11-78. - Smoking prohibited in outdoor areas in city parks. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or chew tobacco on the grounds of any public park operated by the City of Parkland. 
(2)  A law enforcement officer may issue a citation to any person in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(3)  Penalty. Any person issued a citation pursuant to this section shall be deemed to be charged with a civil infraction. A fine of twenty-five ($25.00) shall be assessed for each violation of this section. 
(4)  This section shall not apply to any person smoking within a motor vehicle that is within a city park, whether or not located in a parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 2005-01, § 2, 3-2-2005) 
Sec. 11-79. - Dog park regulations. 
    The dog park known as "Barkland" is an unsupervised facility and users enter at their own risk. By entering this facility owners expressly understand and accept that the city is not responsible for any and all damages which may be caused by their dog or other dogs. Owners and those with custody of a dog are legally responsible for their dogs and any injury they may cause and for complying with the following regulations while in the park: 
A.  Barkland is open daily from 7:30 a.m. to sunset. All persons and dogs must vacate the park when it is not open. 
B.  All dogs must have current rabies shots and a current rabies tag and license displayed on their collar or harness at all times. 
C.  All dog waste must be disposed of immediately and completely. 
D.  If a dog becomes aggressive or is provoking others, it must be removed from the park immediately. 
E.  Owners or those with custody of a dog must be with the dog at all times and may bring a maximum of two (2) dogs per person per visit. 
F.  Dogs must have a collar and be held by a leash when entering or exiting the park. Dog owners or those with custody of a dog must carry a leash for each dog in their care while in the park. 
G.  Dogs that are in heat or sick are not allowed in the park. 
H.  No animals other than dogs are permitted. 
I.  Puppies under four (4) months of age are not permitted in the park. 
J.  Children under the age of twelve (12) must be supervised by an adult at all times. 
K.  If a dog digs, the owner or person with custody of a dog is responsible for stopping its behavior and re-filling the area. 
L.  No food, treats, alcoholic beverages (soft drinks and water are allowed), strollers, bicycles, or children's toys are allowed in the dog park. 
M.  Choke, prong, pinch and spike collars are not allowed in the park. 
N.  Professional dog trainers are not permitted to use this facility for training. 
O.  Dog pools are prohibited. 
P.  Use of this facility shall be for a dog park; any other use is prohibited. 
Q.  All dog bites or injuries must be reported to a park ranger. Park rangers can be reached by calling (954) 913-0496. 
Dogs and/or their owners (or those with custody of a dog) who violate these rules are subject to removal from the park and possible suspension of the right to use the park. The city reserves the right to refuse entry to dogs and/or their owners into Barkland for the reasons of health, safety, and prior offenses or for the comfort of all patrons and/or their pets. 
(Ord. No. 2012-02, § 2(11-79), 2-1-2012) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2009-29, § 1, adopted Sept. 14, 2009, repealed § 11-79 which pertained to helmets required for riding horses and other equine animals and derived from Ord. No. 2005-21, §§ 1, 2, adopted Feb. 15, 2006. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2012-02, § 2, adopted Feb. 1, 2012, further amended section 11-79 by adding dog park regulations. 
Sec. 11-80. - Background checks in organized sport. 
(a)  All city-recognized sports organizations that utilize any city facility, court or playing field shall be required to comply with the standards and requirements of this section. The local level governing board of each city-recognized sports organization shall be required to certify compliance with this requirement as set forth herein. This shall be a condition of the authorized use of the fields by the particular city-recognized sports organization governed by the local level of governing board. The city manager or his/her designee is hereby authorized and directed to prohibit any city-recognized sports organization which does not comply with these requirements from utilizing any city facility, court or playing field. 
(b)  The city hereby adopts the following criteria for exclusion of adult managers, coaches and any other person eighteen (18) years of age or older, who has any supervisory or coaching responsibility, regardless of title or designation including league board members and "buddy" volunteers (hereinafter referred to as volunteer). Any volunteer shall be disqualified from participating as a volunteer on city-owned fields if the person has been found guilty of any one (1) of the following crimes (guilty means that a person was found guilty following a trial, entered a guilty plea, entered a no contest plea, accompanied by a court finding of guilty, regardless of whether there was an adjudication of guilt or a withholding of guilt): 
    Sex Offenses: 
    All sex offenses, regardless of the amount of time since the offense (examples include child molestation, rape, sexual assault, sexual battery, sodomy, prostitution, solicitation, indecent exposure or similar offenses). 
    Felonies: 
    All felony offenses involving violence, regardless of the amount of time since the offense. All felony offenses other than violence or sexual offenses within the past ten (10) years. 
    Misdemeanors: 
    All misdemeanor violent offenses within the past seven (7) years (examples include simple assault, battery, domestic violence, hit and run, and similar offenses). 
    All misdemeanor drug and alcohol offenses within the past five (5) years or multiple offenses within the past ten (10) years (examples include driving under the influence, simple drug possession, drunk and disorderly conduct, public intoxication, possession of drug paraphernalia and similar offenses). 
    Any other misdemeanor within the past five (5) years that would be considered a potential danger to children or is directly related to the functions of that volunteer (contributing to the delinquency of a minor, providing alcohol to a minor, theft [if person is handling monies], and related offenses). 
    The city further finds that any volunteer who has been charged with any of the disqualifying offenses above with cases pending in court should not be permitted to volunteer until the official adjudication of the case. 
(c)  The city adopts the standards of the association for screening of volunteers. The city shall require all volunteers to be screened for the above recommended exclusionary criteria once a year as of October 1, 2008; city-recognized sports organizations already in season (as of October 2, 2008) will be exempt until the season commencing after October 2, 2008. Background checks shall be valid from July 1 to June 30 annually. 
(d)  All city-recognized sports organizations that utilize any city facility, court or playing field shall be required to provide the names of all volunteers and the payment of a fee established by the city manager for each volunteer so that the city may undertake the required background screening to determine if the volunteers should be excluded based upon the above-stated criteria. No volunteer shall be permitted to participate in the activities of a city-recognized sports organization until the city has received the results of the background check and a finding has been made that the volunteer is not disqualified. The city shall make arrangements with a qualified entity to undertake the background screening. The city manager shall authorize an approved set of forms to implement the requirements of this section; all city-recognized sports organizations shall supply the information required by the form as a requirement of this section. The standards as set forth in this section shall be applied by the background screening entity. The background screening entity shall undertake the background screening and provide the results to the city. The results shall be simply a statement of whether the specific volunteer satisfies the criteria or should be excluded by failing to satisfy the criteria set forth above. If the determination by the background screening entity contracted by the city is that the volunteer does not meet the criteria set forth herein, then the city shall provide said notice to the city-recognized sports organizations and the volunteer shall not be permitted to participate in any city-recognized sports organization activity on any city facility, court or playing field as a manager, coach, supervisor or assistant. All city-recognized sports organizations using any city facility, court or playing field shall comply with these requirements and shall not permit any volunteer who has not satisfied the exclusionary criteria to participate in violation of this section. 
(e)  The sports policy of the city as set forth in Resolution No. 2007-42A shall be amended to include this section. 
(f)  Upon receiving results of background screenings from the city, each city-recognized sports organization shall notify its participants of all coaches who have been approved though the screening process. 
(Ord. No. 2008-24, § 2, 10-1-2008; Ord. No. 2009-30, § 2, 11-18-2009; Ord. No. 2011-10, § 2, 4-21-2011) 
ARTICLE VIII. - IDENTIFICATION ON COMMERCIAL VEHICLES[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to instructions by the city, Ord. No. 89-29, §§ 1-3, adopted Jan. 3, 1990, has been codified herein as Art. VIII; and the provisions of §§ 1-3 have been designated by the editor as §§ 11-81-11-83. 

Sec. 11-81. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words have the meanings indicated: 
    Commercial vehicle: Any vehicle which is used primarily for nonpersonal business activities. Outside lettering or logos on any such vehicle designating a business of any kind shall be one, but not the only, method of establishing its commercial status. The following types of vehicles shall be considered commercial for purposes of this section: 
a.  Truck cab; 
b.  Semitrailer; 
c.  Tractor crane; 
d.  Power shovel; 
e.  Well driller; 
f.  Bus; 
g.  Taxi, limousine and other vehicles for hire; 
h.  Ambulance; 
i.  Wrecker (tow truck); 
j.  Hearse; and 
k.  Any other vehicle meeting the above definition. 
    Operating: The conduct of any business, including the delivery or pickup of any material or items or transportation of goods or laborers to the city to perform tasks or functions of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 89-29, § 1, 1-3-1990; Ord. No. 2006-25, § 2, 10-18-2006) 
Sec. 11-82. - Required. 
    All commercial vehicles operating in the city shall be identified by required outside lettering: 
(1)  All commercial vehicles as defined above shall have permanently displayed on each side of the vehicle the following information: 
a.  The name of the person, natural or corporate, who owns or leases the commercial vehicle; and 
b.  The telephone number of the person, natural or corporate, who owns or leases the commercial vehicle; or 
c.  If the commercial vehicle is owned or leased by a corporation, and said corporation has adopted a company decal or insignia, the corporation may display the corporate decal or insignia in lieu of a. and b. above. 
(2)  The above information shall be in bold letters and numerals at least two (2) inches high distinctly contrasting in color with the background and permanently affixed to the vehicle in such a manner as to be readily distinguished from a distance of not less than thirty-five (35) feet. 
(Ord. No. 89-29, § 2, 1-3-1990) 
Sec. 11-83. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person who is convicted of a violation of section 11-82 by a court of competent jurisdiction shall be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or incarceration not to exceed ninety (90) days or both. 
(Ord. No. 89-29, § 3, 1-3-1990) 
Secs. 11-84, 11-85. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - WATER SHORTAGE EMERGENCY GUIDELINES[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- Pursuant to instructions by the city, Ord. No. 90-1, adopted Feb. 7, 1990, has been codified herein as Art. IX; and the provisions of §§ 1-9 and 12 of said ordinance have been designated by the editor as §§ 11-86-11-95; §§ 10 and 11, repealer and severability, respectively, have not been codified herein. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 11-86. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future; words in the plural include the singular; and words in the singular include the plural. The word shall is always mandatory and not merely directory: 
    City: The City of Parkland, Florida 
    District: The South Florida Water Management District (SFWMD or the district). 
    Emergency: A situation where plans implemented in response to a water shortage are insufficient to protect the public health, safety or welfare, including fire protection for human and animal life and real properties, fish or aquatic life, a public water supply or recreational, commercial, industrial, agricultural or other reasonable uses. 
    Person: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
    Water shortage: When insufficient water is available to meet the requirements of the South Florida Water Management District permit system; or when conditions are such as to require temporary reduction in total use within the area to protect water resources from serious harm; or when it is determined that a public water system has become seriously affected by lack of plant capacity to treat water demanded, saltwater intrusion, lack of water pressure due to mechanical failure or lack of supply; or where the SFWMD declares an emergency related to a water shortage; or where sufficient water is not available to meet present or anticipated needs for persons using the water resource; or any other manifestation of insufficient water availability. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 1, 2-7-1990; Ord. No. 2007-14, § 1, 6-6-2007; Ord. No. 2009-16D, § 2, 4-15-2009) 
Sec. 11-87. - Jurisdiction. 
    The provisions of this article apply to all persons using water within the corporate limits of the city when the city or SFWMD declares a water shortage or water shortage emergency. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 2, 2-7-1990; Ord. No. 2007-14, § 2, 6-6-2007) 
Sec. 11-88. - Application of article. 
(a)  Water conservation measures shall be invoked by the city commission by resolution where 
(1)  The SFWMD determines and declares a water shortage or determines that a water shortage emergency exists within a geographical area that includes the city; or 
(2)  The city commission determines by resolution that a reduction in water consumption is necessary. Said resolution of the city commission shall be reduced to writing and shall designate the items of section 11-89 below which shall be included in the restrictions or curtailment to the extent necessary to alleviate the specific water shortage or water shortage emergency. 
(b)  Where the city commission declares that a reduction in consumption is necessary pursuant to subsection (a)(2) above, the regulations promulgated pursuant to such resolution (see section 11-89 below) shall apply to all city consumers of water. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 3, 2-7-1990; Ord. No. 2007-14, § 3, 6-6-2007) 
Sec. 11-89. - Conservation measures. 
    Upon a determination that a water shortage condition exists, the city commission may order the restriction or curtailment of the use of water to the extent necessary to alleviate the water shortage condition and may implement any or all of the following: 
(1)  Restricted uses. Uses of water to be restricted or curtailed include but are not limited to the following: 
a.  The sprinkling, watering or irrigating of shrubbery, trees, lawns, grass, ground covers, plants, vines, gardens, vegetables, including the specification of certain days, hours or periods of time as well as place limitations, when lawns and shrubbery may be watered. 
b.  The washing of automobiles, trucks trailers, railroad cars, mobile homes, campers, boats or any other type of mobile equipment. 
c.  The washing of sidewalks, driveways, filling station aprons, porches, exteriors of homes, apartments or other outdoor surfaces. 
d.  The operation of any ornamental fountain or other structure using water with or without a recirculating system. 
e.  The operation of air-conditioning without a recirculation system. 
f.  Swimming and wading pools not using a filter and recirculating system. 
g.  The escape of water through defective plumbing which means to knowingly allow water to escape through a system that is in disrepair. 
h.  Hotels, motels and restaurants shall be restricted to the minimum amount of water necessary to conduct operations and shall curtail or prohibit any use of water, including but not limited to the use of water to serve a customer in a restaurant unless requested by a customer. 
i.  Miscellaneous uses of water from hydrants for construction purposes, fire drills, dust control or any purpose other than firefighting. 
j.  Other restrictions required by the SFWMD shall be applicable to the use of water in the city. 
(2)  Additionally, all restrictions as declared by SFWMD which are applicable to the city shall immediately be effective in the city and any violation of these restrictions shall be a violation of this article. 
(3)  Extension of water service. A restriction on applications to begin a new use or modify an existing use requiring water service connections, meters, service lines, pipeline extensions, mains or other water service facilities. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 4, 2-7-1990; Ord. No. 2007-14, § 4, 6-6-2007) 
Sec. 11-90. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-14, § 5, adopted June 6, 2007, repealed § 11-90, which pertained to basis for conservation measures and derived from Ord. No. 90-1, § 5, adopted Feb. 7, 1990. 
Sec. 11-91. - Daily restrictions. 
    The South Florida Water Management District restrictions shall be the restrictions for all water consumers in the city unless specified otherwise and all provisions of Florida Administrative Code, Chapter 40E-21, as amended from time to time, shall be applicable to the city. Any violation of that Chapter or any rule or order promulgated by the SFWMD shall be a violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 6, 2-7-1990; Ord. No. 2007-14, § 6, 6-6-2007) 
Sec. 11-92. - Exception to maintain sanitation. 
    The city commission upon the recommendation of the Broward County Health Department or Department of Environmental Regulation or upon its own recognizance shall have the authority to permit a reasonable use of water in any case necessary to maintain adequate health and sanitation standards. A letter from the appropriate agency to the city shall be required to permit such reasonable use of water during a water shortage or water shortage emergency situation. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 9, 2-7-1990) 
Sec. 11-93. - Water users to accept provisions of article. 
    No water service shall be furnished to any person in the city unless that person agrees to accept all the provisions contained in this article. The acceptance of water service from the city shall be in itself the acceptance of the provisions thereof. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 12, 2-7-1990) 
Sec. 11-94. - Enforcement by police officers. 
    Every police officer of the city shall, in connection with his duties imposed by law, diligently enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 7, 2-7-1990) 
Sec. 11-95. - Penalties. 
    Violation of any provision of this article shall be subject to the following penalties: A fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per incident; City Resolution No. 2007-58 is hereby incorporated to provide a graduated scale of fines. 
(Ord. No. 90-1, § 8, 2-7-1990; Ord. No. 2007-14, § 7, 6-6-2007) 
Sec. 11-96. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2 - WATER RESTRICTIONS VIOLATIONS 

Sec. 11-97. - Application. 
    This division shall apply to the violation of any restriction on the use of water, or violations of section 11-86 through 11-96 (collectively referred to as water restrictions). 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 1, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 11-98. - Authorized agent. 
    Code inspector shall mean any authorized agent or employee of the city who has been assigned the duty of code compliance by the city manager or city commission. A Broward County Sheriff's officer or deputy shall be considered a code inspector. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 2, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 11-99. - Appointed. 
    A code enforcement special master appointed by the city commission of the City of Parkland shall have authority to hear alleged violations of water restrictions and impose the fines as authorized by city ordinance or as otherwise authorized by applicable law upon a finding of a violation of any water restriction. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 3, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 11-100. - Authority. 
    Code inspectors shall have authority to cite persons in violation of water restrictions pursuant to the procedures set forth herein. Upon a determination that a violation of a water restriction exists, the code inspector shall provide a notice to the person violating the water restriction. The city hereby declares that any violation of a water restriction shall be the joint and severable responsibility of the person directly responsible for the water restriction violation and, if different, the owner of the property upon which the violation occurs. All notices provided herein shall be by one of the following methods: 
(1)  Certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of the property as listed in the tax collector's offices for tax notices; or 
(2)  Hand delivery by a law enforcement officer or code inspector; or 
(3)  Leaving the notice at the location where the violation occurred with any person above fifteen (15) years of age residing at the location, provided the person is informed of the contents of the notice; or 
(4)  Where certified mail, return receipt method is used (as set forth above in subsection (1) and said notice is returned as unclaimed or refused, notice may be served by publication or posting as follows: 
a.  The notice shall be published once during each week for four (4) consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in Broward County; or 
b.  In lieu of publication as set forth above, the notice may be posted at least fourteen days prior to any hearing to be held on the violation in at least two (2) locations, one of which shall be on the property upon which the violation is alleged to exist, and the other which shall be at city hall. 
For a posted notice, there shall be a proof of posting by affidavit by the person posting the notice, which affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted and the date and places of its posting. 
(5)  In a case of commercial premises, leaving the notice with the manager or other person in charge. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 4, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 11-101. - Violation notices. 
    All violation notices shall state the nature of the violation, the date it occurred, and shall provide the date, time and location of a hearing before the special master at which the special master shall make a determination as to whether a violation exists. The notice shall also state that the respondent shall have the right at the hearing to provide all defenses and relevant evidence related to the charge. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 5, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 11-102. - Hearings. 
    All hearings shall be scheduled by the code enforcement inspector in conjunction with the special master. Each case before the special master related to water restrictions shall be presented by the code inspector or an attorney selected by the city for the purposes of presenting the case. If the city prevails in prosecuting a case before the special master, it shall be entitled to recover all costs incurred in prosecuting the case. Such costs may be included in the lien provided pursuant to the procedures set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 6, 4-2-2008) 
Sec. 11-103. - Testimony. 
    A special master shall hear the cases set on the agenda for the particular date. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded by electronic device or stenographer. The special master shall take testimony from the code inspector, the alleged violator, and any persons they deem to possess relevant evidence. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. At the conclusion of the hearing, the special master shall make a determination as to whether a violation exists, and if so, the amount of the fine. The findings shall be reduced to a written order. If the fine is not paid within ninety (90) days of the written order, the city may record a copy of the order in the public records, the recordation of which shall constitute a lien on the respondent's property. The city may attach an affidavit to the order, as part of a notice of code lien, which shall include the amount of costs incurred in the prosecution (including overtime costs), together with the amount of the fine; the notice of code lien shall include the costs as set forth in the affidavit. 
(Ord. No. 2008-11, § 7, 4-2-2008) 
Secs. 11-104-11-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - NEWSRACKS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 93-9, adopted January 5, 1994, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of § 1 as Art. X, §§ 11-111-11-117 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Traffic motor vehicles, Ch. 20; land development, Ch. 22. 

Sec. 11-111. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the words below shall have the following meanings: 
    Designated area shall mean those areas depicted on exhibit A [of Ordinance No. 93-9] for location of newsracks. 
    Distributor shall mean the person, individual, partnership, corporation, association, firm, company, organization, or any other legal entity owning or responsible for placing or maintaining a newsrack in a public right-of-way. 
    Newsrack shall mean any self-service or coin-operated box, container, storage unit or other dispenser installed, used, or maintained for the display, sale or distribution of audio, visual, written or printed material, including, but not limited to, magazines, newspapers, news periodicals, advertising, circulars, books, pictures, photographs, records and videos. 
    Newsrack location shall mean an area where newsracks are located, containing from one (1) to eight (8) newsracks. 
    Operator shall mean the entity or person who places reading material in the newsrack, the owner of the reading material placed in the newsrack, or the entity or person with custody or control of the newsrack. 
    Owner shall mean the entity or person that owns the newsrack or has a leasehold interest in the newsrack or a license to use the newsrack. 
    Parkway shall mean any area within a right-of-way which is not a pathway or roadway. 
    Pathway shall mean any surface provided for the use of pedestrians and bicycles riders or any equestrian riders. 
    Public property shall mean parks, squares, plazas and any and all other real property owned by the city. 
    Recovery area shall mean that space as determined by state department of transportation regulations, as promulgated in its "green book", which is measured from the edge of the roadway outward and which is required to be clear of fixed objects. 
    Right-of-way shall mean all that area which is dedicated to use by the public for pedestrian and vehicular travel and includes, but is not limited to, roadways, parkways and pathways. 
    Roadway shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed or ordinarily used for vehicular travel, including a median. 
    Undesignated area shall mean those areas not designated on exhibit A [of Ordinance No. 93-9.] 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
Sec. 11-112. - Placement standards. 
    No newsrack [shall be] located in the public right-of-way or on public property: 
(1)  Within five (5) feet of any marked crosswalk, mailbox, driveway or curbcut. 
(2)  Within ten (10) feet of any fire hydrant, fire call box or other emergency facility. 
(3)  Within ten (10) feet ahead of, and ten (10) feet in the rear of, any traffic-related sign. 
(4)  Within that part of a five-foot radius of the outer end of any bus bench between the bus bench and any roadway. 
(5)  At any location whereby the clear space for the passageway of pedestrians would be reduced to less than five (5) feet. 
(6)  Within five (5) feet of, or on any public property improved with, landscaping measured from the edge of the flowers, shrubs, trees and other landscaping located on public property or rights-of-way. 
(7)  Within twenty (20) feet of any police station driveway, fire station driveway, ambulance station driveway, entrance to hospital emergency room or other emergency facility. 
(8)  If there is, within five hundred (500) feet on the same block, another newsrack (which regularly contains the same newspaper or periodical), provided that the distance shall be one thousand (1,000) feet from designated areas. As used herein, "block" shall mean one (1) side of a street between two (2) consecutive intersecting streets. 
(9)  On a roadway. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
Sec. 11-113. - Installation, appearance and maintenance. 
    After January 5, 1994, all newsracks erected, maintained or operated within a public right-of-way or other public property in the city shall conform to the following standards: 
(1)  No more than eight (8) newsracks shall be permitted at each newsrack location. In the undesignated areas of the city, each newsrack location will be selected by the first distributor to choose that location for their newsrack. In order to provide fair access to all publications, space assignment shall be made based solely on first-come, first-served basis. No two (2) groupings of newspapers shall be located within five hundred (500) feet of each other on the same side of any roadway; provided that, in designated areas where newsracks have been erected, no newsrack or grouping of same shall be located within one thousand (1,000) feet of the newsracks located in such designated areas. 
(2)  No advertising shall be permitted upon newsracks other than that relating to information contained in the newspaper or periodical located in the newsrack. Advertisements for products for sale are prohibited. 
(3)  No newsrack shall exceed fifty-four (54) inches in height, thirty-eight (38) inches in width or twenty (20) inches in depth for single newsrack and seventy-six (76) inches in width for double-wide newsrack. Triple newsracks are prohibited. A maximum of one (1) double newsrack shall be permitted at each location. 
(4)  Each newsrack shall be constructed, installed and maintained in a safe and secure condition, and shall be sufficiently weighted to avoid being vandalized or becoming a hazard in severe weather. However, no newsrack or group of newsracks shall weigh, in the aggregate, in excess of one hundred eighty (180) pounds when empty, unless easily separable. 
(5)  Each newsrack shall be maintained in a clean, neat and attractive condition and in good repair at all times so that: 
a.  It is reasonably free of dirt and grease. 
b.  It is reasonably free of chipped, faded, peeling and cracked paint in the visible painted areas thereof. 
c.  It is reasonably free of rust and corrosion in the visible unpainted metal areas thereon. 
d.  The clear plastic or glass parts thereof, if any, through which the publications therein are viewed are unbroken and reasonably free of cracks, dents, blemishes and discoloration. 
e.  The paper or cardboard parts or inserts thereof are reasonably free of tears, peeling or fading. 
f.  The structural parts thereof are not broken or unduly misshapen. 
(6)  No newsrack may be chained, bolted, or affixed to public property. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
Sec. 11-114. - Identification; registration. 
(a)  Each newsrack shall have affixed to it in a readily visible place the phone number of a working telephone service to call to report a malfunction, or to secure a refund in the event of a malfunction of the coin-return mechanism, and shall also provide the name and address of the distributor to receive the notices provided for in this article. 
(b)  Although no permit or license is required prior to the placement of newsracks, any person who places or maintains such a newsrack must provide a written notice with the city manager or his designee of the location or of change in location within three (3) days of its placement or relocation. That notice will establish a space assignment within the provisions of this article. Written notice to the city must contain the name, address and phone number of the owner, operator and distributor, the date it was first located on the right-of-way and the location thereof (with sufficient specificity to permit the city to locate the newsrack and inspect same). The notice may be in the form of a list which may be updated; new locations shall be underlined on each updated list. Failure to provide this notice or to keep the list current and accurate shall be a violation of this article. 
(c)  To defray administrative costs, the owner, operator or distributor shall pay a one-time compliance fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each newsrack installed. The fee shall be paid within thirty (30) days after January 5, 1994, for existing newsracks and ten (10) days after placement of a newsrack in the public right-of-way thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
Sec. 11-115. - Insurance. 
    The owner, operator or distributor shall procure and keep in force liability insurance in a minimum amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) per person and two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) per incident for all newsracks located on city rights-of-way or property. The insurance shall name the city as a named insured and provide that the city shall receive thirty (30) days' notice of any cancellation. The insurance shall be provided within thirty (30) days after January 5, 1994, for existing newsracks and within ten (10) days after location of a newsrack in the right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
Sec. 11-116. - Abandonment. 
    No newsrack shall remain empty for a period of fifteen (15) consecutive days. In the event a newsrack remains empty for that period, it shall be deemed abandoned, and may be removed as set forth in subsection 11-117(d). For the purposes of this section, a newsrack will be declared "empty" under the following circumstances: 
(1)  When it is without any contents; or 
(2)  When the newsrack contains material bearing a date (or other conspicuous evidence which dates it) forty-five (45) days prior to the date it is inspected. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
Sec. 11-117. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The owner, distributor and [or] operator of the newsrack shall be responsible for compliance with all provisions of this article. 
(b)  Upon determination by the city manager, or his designee, that a newsrack has been installed, used or maintained in violation of the provisions of this article, an order to correct the offending conditions shall be issued to the owner, operator or distributor of the newsrack. Such order shall be hand-delivered or mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address required by subsection 11-114(a) above and posted on the offending newsrack. The order shall specifically describe the offending condition and advise of the enforcement provisions contained therein. If no address has been provided, the sole notice shall be provided by posting. 
(c)  Failure to promptly correct the offending condition within ten (10) days after receipt of the order (except that if notice of receipt at the listed address is not received within twenty (20) days, then sufficient notice shall be deemed to have been given) shall be a violation of this article, subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each day the violation exists. The fine will begin accruing on the eleventh day after the receipt of this order or upon the twenty-first day of service as provided above. Violations shall be prosecuted through issuance of a notice to appear and prosecution in the county court (or as set forth in subsection (d). Each day the offense continues shall be a separate violation of this article, except that if the offending owner, operator or distributor pleads not guilty at the arraignment, the fine shall be considered to be stayed after the first day and shall not continue to accrue until a final adjudication of the matter (including all appeals). After the matter is adjudicated (and all appeals concluded), continuance of the same violation shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day and no stay shall be granted by virtue of a not guilty plea. When the owner, operator or distributor of the offending newsrack is not known or identified and the city has made diligent search and inquiry in order to locate the owner, operator or distributor, a copy of the order shall be posted on the newsrack and this shall be deemed sufficient notice of the order to comply and the fine shall begin accruing on the tenth day after posting. 
(d)  If the offending newsrack has been posted pursuant to subsections (b), as a result of the failure of the owner, operator or distributor to provide its address as required herein, or the owner, operator or distributor refuses to accept a notice to appear, and the newsrack remains in violation of this article, or if the newsrack is deemed abandoned (as set forth in section 11-116) for fifteen (15) days, the city may remove same and hold it in storage for sixty (60) days. Thereafter, it may be disposed of as the city deems appropriate. The city shall return news racks held in storage during this period upon satisfactory proof of ownership and payment of a storage charge of three dollars ($3.00) per day of storage. 
(e)  In addition to the procedures set forth, the city shall enforce the provisions of this article by all other lawful means, including, but not limited to, seeking injunctive relief. 
(Ord. No. 93-9, § 1, 1-5-1994) 
ARTICLE XI. - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES IN COMMERCIAL ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 11-118. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Advertisement means a display, notice or other information designed to attract public attention, including, but not limited to handbills, signs, billboards, soundtracks, placards, signboards and written notices. 
    Alcoholic beverages means all beverages containing more than one-half (1/2) of one (1) percent of alcohol by weight, including beer and wine. 
    Areola means the darkened ring surrounding the nipple of a female breast. 
    Commercial means operated for pecuniary gain, which shall be presumed for any establishment which imposes a charge for entrance to view entertainment, or to remain on the premises, or to obtain any goods, items, food, drink or service. For purposes of this article, operating for pecuniary gain shall not depend on actual profit or loss. 
    Establishment means a physical plant or location, or the commercial activities or operations being conducted, or both together, as the context of this article may require. 
    Nude or semi-nude entertainment means any activity where specified anatomical areas are exposed or displayed in public view, or where specified anatomical activities are displayed or performed in public view; this shall include the display of motion pictures which permit the audience to view such areas or activities. 
    Premises means a physical plant or location, which is enclosed by walls or any other enclosing structural device, or which is covered by a single roof or with a single shared entrance from outside. 
    Specified anatomical areas is defined as: 
(1)  Less than completely and opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals and pubic region; or 
b.  Cleavage of the human buttocks; or 
c.  That portion of the human female breast encompassed within an area falling below the horizontal line one would have to draw to intersect a point immediately above the top of the areola, including the areola; this definition shall include the entire lower portion of the human female breast, but shall not include a portion of the cleavage of the human female breast exhibited by a dress, blouse, skirt, leotard, bathing suit or other wearing apparel, provided the areola is not so exposed; and 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely and opaquely covered. 
    Specified sexual activities is defined as: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation, arousal, or tumescence; or 
(2)  Acts of human anilingus, bestiality, buggery, cunnilingus, coprophagy, coprophilia, fellatio, flagellation, masochism, masturbation, necrophilia, pederasty, pedophilia, sadism, sadomasochism, sexual intercourse or sodomy; or 
(3)  Fondling or other touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock, anus, or female breast; or 
(4)  Excretory functions as part of or in connection with the activities set forth in subsections (1) through (3). 
(Ord. No. 2005-22, § 1, 10-19-2005; Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-17-2007) 
Sec. 11-119. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in nude or seminude entertainment in any commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are, or are available to be, sold, dispensed, consumed, possessed or offered for sale or consumption on the premises. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while on the premises of a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are, or are available to be, sold, dispensed, consumed, possessed or offered for sale or consumption on the premises, to display or expose to public view specified anatomical areas or engage in specified sexual activities in public view. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any entertainer, performer or employee, while on the premises of a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are to be sold, dispensed, consumed or offered for sale or consumption on the premises to engage in specified sexual activities in public view. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any entertainer, performer or employee, while on the premises of a commercial establishment regulated under this article, to sit upon or straddle the legs, lap or body of any patron, spectator or other person therein, or to engage in or simulate sexual activity while touching or being touched by such patron, spectator or other person. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in specified sexual activity in public view or to permit the graphic representation of specified anatomical areas or specified sexual activity in public view on the premises of a commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are, or are available to be sold, dispensed, consumed, or offered for sale for consumption on the premises. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, managing or operating any commercial establishment at which alcoholic beverages are, or are available to be sold, dispensed, consumed, possessed or offered for sale or consumption on the premises to knowingly suffer or permit any person on the premises to engage in any conduct prohibited in subsections (a) through (f). 
(Ord. No. 2005-22, § 1, 10-19-2005; Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-17-2007) 
Sec. 11-120. - Proof. 
(a)  It shall be prima facie evidence that a beverage is an alcoholic beverage if proof exists: 
(1)  The beverage in question was or is known as whiskey, moonshine whiskey, shine, rum, gin, tequila, vodka, scotch, scotch whiskey, brandy, beer, malt liquor, or by any other similar name or names; or 
(2)  The beverage was contained in a bottle or can labeled as any of the above names, or a name similar thereto, and the bottle or can bears the manufacturer's insignia, name or trademark. 
(b)  Any person who, by experience in the handling of alcoholic beverages, or who by taste, smell/or drinking of such alcoholic beverages has knowledge of the alcoholic nature thereof, may testify as to his opinion about whether such beverage is an alcoholic beverage. 
(Ord. No. 2005-22, § 1, 10-19-2005; Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-17-2007) 
Sec. 11-121. - Penalties for violation of article. 
    Any person who shall violate any provision of this article shall be guilty of an offense against the city punishable by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or sixty (60) days in prison. Each day a violation exists shall be deemed a separate violation. The occupational license of such establishment at which there are three (3) convictions for violation of the provisions of this article on the property covered by the license during any one-year period shall be revoked by the city after giving a reasonable notice thereof to the holder of such license and affording the holder an opportunity to be heard as to why the revocation should not be issued, as provided in this Code. The city shall also be entitled to enforce this article by injunction in the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 2005-22, § 1, 10-19-2005; Ord. No. 2007-01, § 1, 1-17-2007) 
Secs. 11-122-11-138. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - SEXUAL OFFENDERS AND SEXUAL PREDATORS[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, adopted Dec. 5, 2007, amended the former Art. XII, §§ 11-139-11-142, and enacted a new Art. XII as set out herein. Formerly, Ord. No. 2005-15, § 1, adopted July 6, 2005, set out provisions intended for use as § 11-39. For purposes of classification and to preserve the style of this Code, and at the city's instruction, these provisions have been included as Art. XII, §§ 11-139-11-142. It should be noted that Exhibit A referenced in this article is not set out, but is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 

Sec. 11-139. - Findings and intent. 
(1)  Repeat sexual offenders, sexual offenders who use physical violence, and sexual offenders who prey on children are sexual predators who present an extreme threat to the public safety. Sexual offenders are extremely likely to use physical violence and to repeat their offenses, and most sexual offenders commit many offenses, have many more victims than are ever reported, and are prosecuted for only a fraction of their crimes. This makes the cost of sexual offender victimization to society at large, while incalculable, clearly exorbitant. 
(2)  It is the intent of this section to serve the city's compelling interest to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city by creating areas around locations where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers wherein certain sexual offenders and sexual predators are prohibited from establishing temporary or permanent residence. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 12-5-2007) 
Sec. 11-140. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Child means a person under the age of sixteen (16) years. 
    Child care facility means day nurseries, family day care homes licensed by the department of children and families. 
    Permanent residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for fourteen (14) or more consecutive days. 
    Park means a county or municipal park. 
    Playground means an area set aside by a homeowners association of the city for use by minors to play or an area set aside by a governmental agency devoted to active recreational uses for the primary use of preschool or elementary school age children. 
    School means a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle or secondary (high) school. 
    Sexual offender or sexual predator shall have the meaning ascribed to such term in F.S. § 775.21. 
    Temporary residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of fourteen (14) or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent address, or a place where the person routinely abides, lodges, or resides for a period of four (4) or more consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 1, 8-18-2010) 
Sec. 11-141. - Sexual offender and sexual predator residence prohibition; penalties; exceptions. 
(1)  [Minimum distance from school, park, day care center, etc.] It is unlawful for any person who has been convicted of a violation of Section 794.011, 800.04, 827.071, 847.0135 or 847.0145, Florida Statutes, or a similar offense in another jurisdiction, regardless of whether adjudication has been withheld, in which the victim of the offense was less than sixteen (16) years of age, to establish a permanent residence or temporary residence within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of any school, designated public school bus stop, day care center, park or playground. Persons convicted of a violation of Section 794.05, Florida Statutes, within the previous five (5) years shall be subject to the same restrictions. 
(2)  [Measurement of minimum distance.] For purposes of determining the minimum distance separation, the requirement shall be measured by following a straight line from the outer property line of the permanent residence or temporary residence to nearest outer property line of a school, designated public school bus stop, day care center, park or playground. 
(3)  Penalties. A person who violates this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment; for a second or subsequent conviction of a violation of this section, such person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or imprisonment in the county jail not more than twelve (12) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(4)  Exceptions. A person residing within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of any school, designated public school bus stop, day care center, park, playground, or other place where children regularly congregate does not commit a violation of this section if any of the following apply: 
(i)  The sexual offender or sexual predator established the permanent residence prior to July 1, 2005. 
(ii)  The sexual offender or sexual predator was a minor when he/she committed the offense and was not convicted as an adult. 
(iii)  The sexual offender or sexual predator is a minor. 
(iv)  The school, designated public school bus stop or day care center within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of the sexual offender or sexual predator's permanent residence was opened after the person established the permanent residence. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2010-02, § 1, 2-17-2010; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 2(11-39(C)), 8-18-2010; Ord. No. 2011-34, § 2, 1-4-2012) 
Sec. 11-142. - Property owners prohibited from renting real property to certain sexual offenders and sexual predators; penalties. 
(1)  It is unlawful to let or rent any place, structure, or part thereof, trailer or other conveyance, with the knowledge that it will be used as a permanent residence or temporary residence by any person prohibited from establishing such permanent residence or temporary residence pursuant to this article, if such place, structure, or part thereof, trailer or other conveyance, is located within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of any school, designated public school bus stop, day care center, park, playground, or other place where children regularly congregate. 
(2)  Prior to letting, renting or leasing any place, structure, or part thereof, trailer or other conveyance for use as a permanent or temporary residence that is located within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of a school, designated public school bus stop, day care center, park, playground, or other place where children regularly congregate and annually thereafter if a rental agreement is entered into, the owner or lessor shall obtain confirmation of a nationwide search from the Broward Sheriff's Office, Parkland District or other law enforcement agency that the prospective renter, lessee or adult resident is not a registered sexual offender or sexual predator as a result of a conviction of a sexual offense as defined herein. 
(3)  A property owner's failure to comply with provisions of this section shall constitute a violation of this section, and shall subject the property owner to all code enforcement provisions and procedures as permitted in the city Code (through section 4.5 of the city Code or through prosecution in court), or as otherwise permitted by law, including, but not limited to injunctive or other relief in a court of law in order to secure compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2007-26, § 1, 12-5-2007; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 3(11-39(D)), 8-18-2010; Ord. No. 2010-25, § 6(11-39(D)), 11-17-2010) 
Sec. 11-143. - Sexual offender and sexual predator access to parks, playgrounds and child care facilities restricted; penalties. 
(1)  It is unlawful for a sexual offender or sexual predator convicted of a sexual offense, as defined in the section above, to knowingly be present in a municipal park or a playground, when a child under the age of sixteen (16) years is present, unless the sexual offender or sexual predator is the parent or legal guardian of a child present in the park or playground. Prior to any citation for a violation under this section, the alleged violator shall be given an opportunity to promptly leave the park or playground. 
(2)  It is unlawful for a sexual offender or sexual predator convicted of a sexual offense, as defined herein above, to knowingly enter or remain in a child care facility ("facility") or on its premises unless the sexual offender or sexual predator: 
(a)  Is dropping off or picking up a child registered at the facility and is the parent or guardian of said child; and 
(b)  Remains under the supervision of a facility supervisor or his or her designee while on the facility premises. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, § 4(11-39(E)), 8-18-2010) 
Sec. 11-144. - Loitering or prowling in child safety zone; penalties. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any sexual offender or sexual predator: 
(a)  To loiter or prowl with the intent to commit a sexual offense as listed herein above in this article;
