(b)  While knowingly within five hundred (500) feet of a school, school bus stop, child care center or playground when children are present; and 
(c)  To engage in overt conduct that, under the circumstances, manifests an intent to commit a sexual offense as listed herein above in this article. 
(2)  Conduct which may, under the circumstances, be deemed adequate to manifest an intent to commit a sexual offense as listed herein above in this article, but is not limited to, conduct such as the following: 
(a)  Making sexual conversation or sexual remarks to a child; 
(b)  Making lewd or sexual gestures to a child, or exposing sexual organs to a child; 
(c)  Giving gifts of candy, money, music or other items to a child to which he or she is not related or acquainted. 
(3)  Unless flight by the sexual offender or sexual predator or other circumstance makes it impracticable, a law enforcement officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense under this section, afford the sexual offender or sexual predator an opportunity to explain his or presence and conduct. No sexual offender or sexual predator shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the law enforcement officer did not comply with this procedure or if it is proven at trial that the explanation given by the sexual offender or sexual predator is true, and that the sexual offender or sexual predator had no intent to commit a sexual offense. 
(4)  As used in this section, a sexual offender or sexual predator is related to a child if he or she is the father, mother, step-father, step-mother, grandparent, sibling, cousin, aunt, uncle or resides with the child. As used in this section a sexual offender or sexual predator is acquainted with a child if he or she has been introduced to the child in the presence of an adult with legal authority to supervise the child. 
    This provision is not intended to limit or affect the applicability of any general loitering and prowling statutes to sexual offenders or sexual predators, including, but not limited to, F.S. § 856.021. 
(Ord. No. 2010-18, § 5(11-39(F)), 8-18-2010) 
Secs. 11-145-11-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - ADVERTISING OF VEHICLES, BOATS AND OTHER SIMILAR ITEMS FOR SALE ALONG CITY RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 11-171. - Public right-of-way easement. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place on the public right-of-way (which shall include ingress and egress easements dedicated to the public) any motor vehicle, any boat, any trailer, or any personal watercraft with any signage or other communicative material indicating that it is for sale, rent, or otherwise available for use by someone other than the owner. It shall also be a violation for any person to permit to be placed on his or her property, any motor vehicle, any boat, any trailer, or any personal watercraft with any signage or other communicative material indicating that it is for sale, rent, or otherwise available for use by someone other than the owner, except where said vehicle is lawfully parked on a paved or other hard surface private driveway or within an enclosed structure. 
(Ord. No. 2005-19, § 1, 9-21-2005) 
Sec. 11-172. - Violation. 
    No motor vehicles, boats, trailers, or personal watercraft shall be permitted to remain on the right-of-way for a period of twenty-four (24) consecutive hours. Any motor vehicle, boat, trailer, or personal watercraft violating this requirement shall be towed by the city after a twenty-four-hour notice (containing notice that the motor vehicle, boat, trailer, or personal watercraft will be towed if not removed in twenty-four (24) hours and containing the necessary retrieval information) which shall be affixed to the motor vehicle, boat, trailer, or personal watercraft. The owner of the motor vehicle, boat, trailer, or personal watercraft shall be responsible for retrieving same and the costs thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2005-19, § 2, 9-21-2005) 
Chapter 12 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; licenses, Ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Peddlers at camp meetings, F.S. § 871.03; solicitation of funds, F.S. Ch. 496. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-1. - Definitions. 
    Canvasser or solicitor shall mean any individual, whether resident of the city or not, traveling either by foot, automobile, motor truck, or any other type of conveyance, from place to place, from house to house, or from street to street, taking or attempting to take orders for sale of goods, wares, merchandise, personal property or services of any nature whatsoever, whether or not such individual has, carries, or exposes for sale a sample of the subject of such sale or whether or not he is collecting advance payments on such sales. Such definition shall not include any person who: 
(1)  For himself, or for another person, firm or corporation hires, leases, uses or occupies any hotel or motel room within the city for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples within the hotel or motel, taking orders for future delivery only. 
(2)  Solicits or canvasses on behalf of a charitable organization. 
(3)  Solicits or canvasses on behalf of a political party, candidate, or political viewpoint. 
(4)  Solicits or canvasses on behalf of public or private schools raising funds for schools teaching grades kindergarten through grade twelve (12), colleges, and universities. 
(5)  Solicits or canvasses on behalf of a religious institution. 
    Charitable organization , as defined by F.S. § 496.404, means a person who is or holds herself or himself out to be established for any benevolent, educational, philanthropic, humane, scientific, artistic, patriotic, social welfare or advocacy, public health, environmental conservation, civic, or other eleemosynary purpose, or a person who in any manner employs a charitable appeal as the basis for any solicitation or an appeal that suggests that there is a charitable purpose to any solicitation. 
    Religious institution, as defined by F.S. § 496.404, means a church, ecclesiastical or denominational organization, or established physical place for worship in this state at which nonprofit religious services and activities are regularly conducted and carried on and includes those bona fide religious groups that do not maintain specific places of worship. The term also includes a separate group or corporation that forms an integral part of a religious institution that is exempt from federal income tax under Section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code and that is not primarily supported by funds solicited outside its own membership or congregation. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 2, 5-5-1982; Ord. No. 2017-02, § 2, 3-15-2017) 
Sec. 12-2. - Organizations-Exemptions. 
(a)  Organizations claiming exempt status under section 12-1 shall provide the city with a copy of the registration statement required pursuant to F.S. § 496.405. 
(b)  Soliciting or canvassing by persons on behalf of a charitable organization, on behalf of a political party, political candidate or political viewpoint or on behalf of a religious institution shall not take place before 9:00 a.m. or one-half hour after sunset. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 2, 5-5-1982; Ord. No. 2017-02, § 2, 3-15-2017) 
Sec. - 12-3. Purpose and intent. 
(a)  The city commission of the City of Parkland wishes to protect the privacy of residents who do not desire door-to-door solicitation or canvassing as well as the privacy of those residents who wish to receive door-to-door solicitation or canvassing only during certain desired hours. In addition, the city commission wishes to protect and further the rights of residents who may want to receive door-to-door solicitation or canvassing at all times. The city commission is no less cognizant of the First Amendment protections afforded to door-to-door soliciting and canvassing and the concomitant duty of the elected officials to safeguard and protect such First Amendment rights. 
(b)  It is the purpose and intent of the city commission to balance and weigh these sometimes competing concerns in creating this section so as to enact narrowly tailored content and viewpoint neutral regulation which satisfies the city's recognized and significant governmental interests in safeguarding resident privacy by using what is perceived to be very restrictive and minimally intrusive regulatory means in view of the equal adverse impact commercial and noncommercial door-to-door soliciting and canvassing have on resident privacy, all while providing for ample alternative avenues for communication. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02, § 2, 3-15-2017) 
Editor's note- Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 2017-02, adopted Mar. 15, 2017, amended § 12-3 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 12-3 pertained to other exemptions, and derived from Ord. No. 68, adopted May 5, 1982. 
Sec. 12-4. - Uninvited solicitation and canvassing. 
(a)  This section will not operate to totally ban door-to-door soliciting and canvassing, but will permit the residents to protect themselves from solicitors or canvassers by posting "No Solicitation" signs upon their property when door-to-door solicitation or canvassing is not desired, all while leaving unaffected the ability of door-to-door solicitors and canvassers to contact residents desiring same and while leaving unaffected other methods of solicitation or canvassing (direct mail solicitation or canvassing, telephone solicitation or canvassing, soliciting or canvassing in areas other than residential areas, etc.). 
(b)  "Solicitor" or "canvasser" as used in this section means all persons seeking funds or services of any kind for any purpose or seeking to sell, give or in any way dispose of goods, services, wares, merchandise, newspapers, or written material of any kind, regardless of whether the person is engaged in a commercial transaction or in a religious, educational, political, scientific, philanthropic, benevolent, fraternal, charitable or any other noncommercial activity. 
(c)  No solicitor or canvasser shall willfully enter upon the property of a private residence when the owner or occupant thereof has posted or placed near or at the entrance of the property a sign containing the words "No Solicitation" or a substantially similar message in letters easily read by a person approaching the property. Said signs shall be posted or placed in a manner and in such position as to be clearly noticeable to a person approaching the property. 
(d)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any person or business representative invited upon the property by an inhabitant of the property or by an inhabitant's agent or to the distribution of advertising materials through the U.S. Postal Services or to the distribution of any newspaper of general circulation. 
(Ord. No. 2017-02, § 2, 3-15-2017) 
Secs. 12-5-12-14. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT 

Sec. 12-15. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any solicitor or canvasser as defined in section 12-1 of this chapter to engage in such business within the residentially zoned districts of the city without first obtaining a permit in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 1, 5-5-1982) 
Sec. 12-16. - Application. 
(a)  At the time of filing the application, a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) shall be paid to the public safety department to cover the cost of investigation of the facts stated therein, which fee shall be nonrefundable. 
(b)  Applicants for permit under this chapter must file with the public safety department a sworn application in writing in duplicate on a form to be furnished by the city. 
(c)  Each applicant shall submit the following information: 
(1)  Name and description of applicant; date of birth, Social Security number and driver's license number. 
(2)  Permanent home address and full local address of the applicant. 
(3)  A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be sold or the service to be rendered. 
(4)  If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with credentials establishing the exact relationship. 
(5)  The length of time between 9:00 a.m. and one-half hour after sunset for which the right to do business is desired. 
(6)  The place where the goods or property proposed to be sold, or orders taken for the sale thereof, are manufactured or produced, where such goods or products are located at the time the application is filed, and the proposed method of delivery. 
(7)  The names of at least two (2) reliable property owners of the county who will certify as to the applicant's good character and business responsibility, or, in lieu of references, other available evidence as to the good character and business responsibility of the applicant which will enable the city to evaluate the character and business responsibility of the applicant. 
(8)  A sworn statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime, misdemeanor or violation of any municipal ordinance; if so, the nature of the offense and the punishment or penalty assessed therefor. 
(d)  There shall be no soliciting before 9:00 a.m. or one-half hour after sunset. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 3, 5-5-1982; Ord. No. 2017-02, § 2, 3-15-2017) 
Sec. 12-17. - Investigation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of each application, the original shall be referred to the public safety director, who shall cause an investigation to be made into the applicant's character and business responsibility. 
(b)  If, as a result of such investigation, the applicant's character or business responsibility is found to be unsatisfactory, the public safety director shall so endorse the application stating the basis for same. 
(c)  The public safety director shall then notify the applicant that his application has been disapproved and that no permit shall be issued. 
(d)  If, as a result of such investigation, the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory, the public safety director shall so endorse the application. 
(e)  The public safety director shall then: 
(1)  Cause to be taken by the public safety department a fingerprint and photograph of the applicant. 
(2)  Upon payment of the prescribed permit fee, deliver to the applicant his permit and issue an identification card. 
(3)  Such permit shall contain the signature and seal of the issuing officer and shall show: 
a.  The name and address of the applicant; 
b.  The amount of fee paid; 
c.  The date of issuance; 
d.  The length of time the same shall be operative; 
e.  The name of the company the applicant represents, if any, as well as; 
f.  The license permit number. 
(4)  Keep permanent records of all permits and identification cards issued. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 4, 5-5-1982; Ord. No. 2017-02, § 2, 3-15-2017) 
Sec. 12-18. - Fees. 
    The permit fee per solicitor or canvasser shall be collected by the public safety director and the charge for such permit shall be thirty-five dollars ($35.00) per year. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 5, 5-5-1982) 
Secs. 12-19-12-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - IDENTIFICATION CARD 

Sec. 12-30. - Required. 
    The public safety department shall issue to each applicant at the time of delivery of his permit an identification card which shall contain the words "Licensed Solicitor" and indicate: 
(1)  The name and address of the solicitor or canvasser; 
(2)  The name of the company he represents; 
(3)  The length of time his permit is valid and the time of day permitted to solicit or canvass; 
(4)  The kind of goods or services to be sold thereunder and contain the applicant's fingerprint and city-sealed photograph. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 6, 5-5-1982) 
Sec. 12-31. - Exhibition of identification card. 
    Solicitors and canvassers are required to exhibit their identification card upon their person at all times when soliciting and/or canvassing under the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 6, 5-5-1982) 
Sec. 12-32. - Records. 
    The public safety department shall maintain a record of all violations of this chapter and shall maintain a record for each permit, identification card and record the reports of convictions therein. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 7, 5-5-1982) 
Secs. 12-33-12-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - REVOCATION AND APPEAL 

Sec. 12-44. - Revocation of permits and identification cards. 
(a)  Permits and identification cards issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the public safety director of the city after notice and public hearing for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement contained in the application for permit or identification card; 
(2)  Fraud, misrepresentation, or false statement made in the course of carrying on his business as a solicitor or as a canvasser; 
(3)  Conviction of any violation of this chapter; 
(4)  Conviction of any crime or misdemeanor involving moral turpitude; or 
(5)  Conducting the business of soliciting or of canvassing in an unlawful manner or in such a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or to constitute a menace to the health, safety or general welfare of the public. 
(b)  Notice of the hearing for revocation of a permit or identification card shall be given by the city in writing, setting forth specifically the ground of complaint and the time and place of hearing. Such notice shall be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permit or identification card holder at his last-known address at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing. Notice of the public hearing shall also be posted at the city hall at least five (5) days prior to the public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 8, 5-5-1982) 
Sec. 12-45. - Appeal. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved by the action of the city in the denial or revocation of a permit or identification card shall have the right to appeal to the city commission of the city. 
(b)  Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the commission, within fourteen (14) days after notice of the action complained of has been mailed to such person's last-known address a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for appeal. 
(c)  The city commission shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant in the same manner as provided in subsection 12-44(b) of this chapter for notice of hearing on revocation. 
(d)  The decision and order of the city commission on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 9, 5-5-1982) 
Sec. 12-46. - Expiration of permit and identification cards. 
(a)  All annual permits and identification cards issued under the provisions of this chapter shall expire on September 30 of each year. 
(b)  Other than annual permits, identification cards shall expire on the date specified in the permit. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 11, 5-5-1982) 
Sec. 12-47. - Enforcement. 
    The public safety department shall have the authority to inspect all moving vehicles operating on the streets and public places of the city as well as any person seen or known to be soliciting or canvassing to determine whether the solicitor or canvasser has complied with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 68, § 12, 5-5-1982) 
Chapter 14 - PUBLIC SAFETY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, Ch. 2; animals, Ch. 3; garbage and refuse, Ch. 7; offenses, ch. 11; peddlers and solicitors, Ch. 12; traffic and motor vehicles, Ch. 20; land development, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Registration of convicted felons by sheriff, F.S. § 943.145; precious metals, F.S. § 812.051; abandoned property, notice, F.S. § 715.05 and Ch. 705; Contraband Forfeiture Act, F.S. § 932.701 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Assessment and collection of fees for police training. 
(a)  There is hereby assessed by the city, in compliance with F.S. § 943.25(8), two dollars ($2.00) as court costs against every person convicted for violation of a state penal or criminal statute or convicted of a municipal or county ordinance, where the offense occurred within the city. 
(b)  In addition, two dollars ($2.00) shall be deducted from every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to such penal statutes or ordinances. 
(c)  However, no such assessment shall be made against any person convicted for violation of any state statute, municipal or county ordinance relating to the parking of vehicles. 
(d)  All such assessments shall be collected by the appropriate court and shall be remitted to the city and earmarked for law enforcement education and training for members of the police department. 
(e)  The use and expenditure of such funds shall be in accordance with education and training programs for law enforcement personnel as determined by the chief of police and in accordance with F.S. § 943.14. 
(Ord. No. 38, § 1, 11-17-1976; Ord. No. 38-A, § 1, 1-6-1982) 
State Law reference- Assessment of county court costs for training, F.S. § 943.25. 
Sec. 14-2. - Key boxes. 
(a)  In all new and existing developments, there shall be installed a key box, at the development's expense, when the city's fire and/or police chief determines that access to or within a structure or an area is unduly difficult because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for life-safety or fire-fighting purposes. The key box shall be a type approved by the city's fire and police chiefs and shall contain: 
(1)  Keys to locked points of ingress, whether on the interior or exterior of such buildings; 
(2)  Keys to locked mechanical equipment rooms; 
(3)  Keys to locked electrical rooms; 
(4)  Keys to other places as directed by the city's fire and/or police chiefs. 
(b)  If at any time the key stored in the lock box changes, then the development is to notify the fire department and supply new keys to the city's fire and police chiefs within twenty-four (24) hours of the lock box change. The fire and police chiefs shall approve the location of the lock boxes. 
(c)  Existing developments shall have six (6) months from the date of adoption of this section to conform as required. 
(d)  Any entity or person who violates any provision of this section or fails to comply therewith shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) and each day said violation shall exist or be permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2006-36, § 1, 11-1-2006) 
Sec. 14-3. - Community automated external defibrillator (AED) and bleeding control kit program. 
(1)  Definition of automated external defibrillators. Automated external defibrillator device. A defibrillator device that: 
(a)  Is commercially distributed in accordance with the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act; 
(b)  Is capable of recognizing the presence or absence of ventricular fibrillation, and is capable of determining without intervention by the user of the device whether defibrillation should be performed; and 
(c)  Upon determining that defibrillation should be performed, is able to deliver an electrical shock to an individual. 
(2)  Definition of bleeding control kit (BCK). A collection of equipment housed in a container that displays the universal medical symbol that is used to attempt to control bleeding from a patient who has suffered a traumatic injury. A bleeding control kit shall contain the following equipment that must be approved by the fire department prior to purchase: 
Regular BCK: 
(a)  Two (2) commercially manufactured tourniquets; 
(b)  Two (2) four-inch pressure dressings; 
(c)  Two (2) compressed gauze pads; 
(d)  Two (2) vented chest seals; 
(e)  Two (2) pairs of x-large medical gloves; 
(f)  One (1) pair of trauma scissors; and 
(g)  One (1) instruction card. 
Large BCK: 
(a)  Eight (8) commercially manufactured tourniquets; 
(b)  Eight (8) four-inch pressure dressings; 
(c)  Eight (8) compressed gauze pads; 
(d)  Eight (8) vented chest seals; 
(e)  Eight (8) pairs of x-large medical gloves; 
(f)  One (1) pair of trauma scissors; and 
(g)  One (1) instruction card. 
(3)  Intent. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city and the purpose of this chapter: 
1.  To promote the public health, safety, and general welfare by requiring the installation of automated external defibrillator devices and bleeding control kits within certain buildings in the city; 
2.  To provide for the inspection of each automated external defibrillator device and bleeding control kit within the city; 
3.  To provide for the payment of automated external defibrillator and bleeding control kit inspection fees; and 
4.  To provide for penalties for non-compliance with this article. 
(4)  Automated external defibrillator devices and bleeding control kits required. 
(a)  Automated external defibrillator devices and regular bleeding control kits (unless otherwise specified) shall be installed in the following locations and buildings located within the geographical boundaries of the city: 
1.  Gymnasiums, fitness centers, and indoor recreational centers in excess of one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet; 
2.  Restaurants, theaters and dining establishments with a one hundred (100) maximum capacity or greater including indoor, outdoor and bar area; 
3.  All hotels and motels; 
4.  Assisted living facilities as defined by F.S. § 429.02, as amended from time to time; 
5.  Pharmacies. A pharmacy is an establishment or institution in which the practice of pharmacy is conducted; drugs, medicines or medicinal chemicals are dispensed or offered for sale, or a sign is displayed bearing the word or words "pharmacist," "pharmacy," "apothecary," "drugstore," "druggist," "medicine store," "drug sundries," "prescriptions filled," or similar words intended to indicate that the practice of pharmacy is being conducted; 
6.  All dental offices in accordance with Florida Administrative Code 64B5-17.015; 
7.  Multi-story occupancies listed in subsections 1. through 6. and/or multi-story office buildings shall place an AED on every other floor beginning on the first floor. The AED shall be placed near the elevator(s) beginning in the first floor lobby (first floor, third floor, etc.). 
8.  Office buildings with a square footage greater than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet; 
9.  Commercial and retail spaces with a square footage greater than thirty-five thousand (35,000) square feet; 
10.  Places of occupancy that hold five hundred (500) or more persons shall have a large bleeding control kit in addition to the required automated external defibrillators. 
(5)  Installation and operation. 
(a)  The city shall inspect all automated external defibrillator and bleeding control kits for operation prior to being placed in service or available for use, and on an annual basis. 
(b)  Automated external defibrillator devices shall be: 
1.  Conspicuously located in plain view of the primary public entrance, with unobstructed access; 
2.  Housed in a cabinet with a clear window in the door, an audible alarm signaling the opening of a door, permanently affixed to a wall, and whose top is no more than forty-eight (48) inches above the floor; 
3.  Located below a sign having a minimum area of seventy (70) square inches and containing the letters "AED" and the universally recognizable symbol, which shall be placed no more than sixty (60) inches, on center, above the floor; 
4.  Readily accessible and immediately available when needed for on-site employees and the general public, including disabled persons; and 
5.  Placed near the elevator(s) in the first floor lobby, if the building contains an elevator. 
(c)  Automated external defibrillator devices shall contain adult and pediatric pads and bandage scissors. Adult living facilities shall be exempt from providing pediatric pads. 
(d)  All automated external defibrillator devices shall be used in accordance with the manufacturer's guidelines. 
(e)  Bleeding control kits shall be located in the same cabinet as automated external defibrillators or: 
1.  Conspicuously located in plain view of the primary public entrance, with unobstructed access; 
2.  Housed in a cabinet with a clear window in the door, an audible alarm signaling the opening of a door, permanently affixed to a wall, and whose top is no more than forty-eight (48) inches above the floor or housed in the automated defibrillator cabinet; 
3.  Located below a sign having a minimum area of seventy (70) square inches and containing the words "BLEEDING CONTROL" and the universally recognizable medical cross, which shall be placed no more than sixty (60) inches, on center, above the floor; 
4.  Readily accessible and immediately available when needed for on-site employees and the general public, including disabled persons; and 
5.  Placed near the elevator(s) in the first floor lobby, if the building contains an elevator. 
(f)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner of the building to: 
1.  Install automated external defibrillator devices; 
2.  Provide all necessary training (as approved by the fire department or as set forth in the manufacturer' specifications) for appropriate use. 
3.  Maintain automated external defibrillator devices and bleeding control kits in accordance with manufacturer's recommended maintenance requirements and as required herein. 
4.  Comply with all other provisions of this section. 
(g)  If an automated external defibrillator device or bleeding control kit, or any part thereof, is removed for repair, a replacement shall be provided within forty-eight (48) hours. 
(h)  If an automated external defibrillator device or bleeding control kit is required to be located within a business, signage containing the letters "AED" and the universally recognizable symbol is required to be placed within the tenant message space on the door and shall be displayed on all external doors of all buildings in which an AED is required. 
(6)  Fees. Fees for automated external defibrillator device permits and inspections shall be set by resolution. 
(7)  Penalties. It shall constitute a violation of the city Code, punishable as provided in this section-to intentionally or willfully: 
(a)  Render an automated external defibrillator device or bleeding control kit inoperative except during such time as the automated external defibrillator device is being serviced, tested, repaired, or recharged, except pursuant to court order; 
(b)  Obliterate the serial number on an automated external defibrillator device or bleeding control kit for purposes of falsifying service records; 
(c)  Improperly service, recharge, repair, test, or inspect an automated external defibrillator device bleeding control kit; 
(d)  Use the inspection certificate of another person; 
(e)  Hold an inspection certificate and allow another person to use said inspection certificate number; 
(f)  Intentionally open an encased automated external defibrillator or bleeding control kit for any purpose other than to provide emergency medical care. It shall not be a violation of this subsection for an owner of property, or an agent thereof, to open their encased automated external defibrillator or bleeding control kit for maintenance, replacement, or inspection; or 
(g)  To otherwise fail to comply with this article. 
(8)  [Penalties.] Failure to comply with any part of this article shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days or by both fine and imprisonment. Each day a violation exists shall be a separate violation. In addition, the city shall also have the right to revoke, refuse to issue, refuse to reissue, refuse to transfer, or refuse to renew any business tax receipt for any facility, business, entity or establishment where the violation occurred until such time as the violation and/or fine is corrected. 
(9)  Requirements and procedures. The following shall be the requirements and procedures for use and training of the AED program: 
(a)  The use and training of an AED shall occur only after a written notification, in a form determined by the city, is made to the fire chief or his/her designee by the individual, entity, organization, or company acquiring an AED. The written notification must contain the facility or business name, street address, specific location of the AED, the number of employees at the facility or business, the name of the AED manufacturer, and model number of each AED. 
(b)  Maintenance and inspection of the AED or bleeding control kit is the responsibility of the occupant and shall be done on a periodic basis, at a minimum annually, as prescribed by the manufacturer and/or certifying agency. Maintenance of the AED device and bleeding control kit shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations. 
(c)  The fire rescue department, or his/her designee, shall verify at a minimum annually, the presence of the AED device, and may inspect any maintenance records and documentation of training to ensure compliance with the community automated external defibrillator program. 
(d)  The City of Parkland and the City of Parkland Fire Rescue Department, or their designee is not liable for any damages experienced by the AED, or any person or entity arising as a result of: 
1.  Business's use or misuse of the equipment or supplies; 
2.  Business's failure to provide services pertaining to the equipment or supplies; or 
3.  Any defects in the equipment or supplies. 
(10)  Applicability. The owner of any existing building and the business owner shall be required to have an automated external defibrillator device or bleeding control kit shall comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 2007-05, § 2, 3-28-2007; Ord. No. 2009-06, § 2, 3-4-2009; Ord. No. 2009-24, § 2, 7-1-2009; Ord. No. 2018-005, 5-16-2018) 
Sec. 14-4. - Emergency medical services fees. 
(a)  The city does hereby impose the following charges for emergency medical services (EMS) rendered to persons within the corporate boundaries to persons within the city and to any parties in unincorporated Broward County that the city may serve by virtue of an interlocal [agreement] with the county: 
1. BLS Service $461.00 2. ALS1 Service 520.00 3. ALS2 Service 663.00 4. Inter-Facility Transfers 520.00 5. Mileage 10.40 6. EMS Standby Fee (3 hr minimum) Per hour per person 57.00 Each additional hour or portion thereof Over 3 hours of EMS standby 57.00  
(b)  It is the intent of the city commission to transfer the costs of certain city services to the individuals who are requesting the services from the city. The administrative and/or user fees charged under this section shall be set forth in a resolution adopted by the city commission. 
(c)  The listing of administrative and/or user fees in this section may not be all inclusive and therefore, other applicable Code chapters and/or provisions may apply in addition to the fees designated in this section. 
(d)  All fees included in this section shall be permitted to be increased yearly, without city commission approval, no greater than the Consumer Price Index ("CPI"). Upon approval by the city commission, through a resolution, an administrative and/or user fee can be increased above the CPI. 
(e)  All fees adopted per this section shall be increased on October 1 of each respective year unless noted otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2011-30, § 2(14-4), 11-2-2011) 
Secs. 14-5-14-12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE[2]

Sec. 14-13. - Police services. 
    Police services for the City of Parkland shall be provided by the Broward County Sheriff's Office (BSO) pursuant to a contract with the Broward County Sheriff's Office. In conjunction with the Broward County Sheriff's Office, the city manager shall determine the manner in which services shall be coordinated with the City of Parkland to carry out the purpose and intent of the contract and to provide police services to the City of Parkland. BSO shall have all powers necessary or attendant to the task and responsibility of providing police services and shall serve as the police department for the city. 
(Ord. No. 2004-04, § 1, 2-18-2004)
