ARTICLE III. - EXPLOSIVES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 98-06, adopted Mar. 3, 1998, repealed §§ 14-21-14-27 in their entirety. Formerly, said sections pertained to fire prevention and control and derived from Ord. No. 85-16, § 1, adopted Aug. 21, 1985. Section 1 also added a new Ch. 8A; however, for purposes of classification, such provisions were codified herein as §§ 14-21-14-42. 

Sec. 14-21. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  This article is intended to supplement F.S. ch. 552, and not to supersede to conflict with provisions thereof. The intent and purpose of this article is hereby declared to adopt chapter 12 of the Broward County Code and all revisions thereto and to provide more stringent regulations and control of explosives in the city, where warranted, for the public safety, health and welfare, and to prevent the possession and use of explosives by unauthorized persons. This article shall be supplemental to the authority of the county under chapter 12, and all county regulations on this subject matter. 
(b)  This article shall apply, at blasting sites, to the use and storage of explosive and blasting agents. Application for licenses required herein shall be made to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. No blasting operations shall take place within the city unless a blasting permit has been issued by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
(c)  Chapter 12 of the Broward County Code of Ordinances is hereby adopted as if fully set forth herein and all amendments thereto shall be deemed part of the ordinance upon adoption by the county. Where Chapter 12 imposes more stringent requirements, those requirements shall supercede those provided for herein. The county shall have concurrent jurisdiction over all issues contained herein and over regulation of blasting and shall have the authority to enforce its regulations within the city independent of anything contained herein. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(1), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-22. - Exceptions. 
    [The following exceptions shall apply to this article:] 
(1)  The Armed Forces of the United States or the state militia. 
(2)  Explosives in forms presented by the official United States Pharmacopeia. 
(3)  The possession, transportation and use of small arms ammunition or special industrial explosive devises. 
(4)  The sale or use of fireworks. 
(5)  The use of explosives or blasting agents by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the United States Secret Service, or police and fire departments acting in their official capacity. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(2), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-23. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory: 
    Airblast. An airborne shock wave resulting from the detonation of explosives. May be caused by burden movement or the release of expanding gas into the air. An airblast may or may not be audible. 
    Blaster. A person employed by a user who detonates or otherwise effects the explosion of an explosive or who is in immediate personal charge and supervision of one (1) or more other persons engaged in such activity. 
    Blasting agent. Any material or mixture, consisting of a fuel and oxidizer, intended for blasting, not otherwise classified as an explosive, in which none of the ingredients is classified as an explosive, provided that the finished product, as mixed and packaged for use or shipment, cannot be detonated by means of a No. 8 test blasting cap when unconfined. Materials or mixtures classified as nitro nitrates by the department of transportation regulations shall be included in this definition. 
    Blasting field inspector. An individual licensed by the state as a blaster with a minimum of five (5) years' experience supervising and/or monitoring the use of explosives. 
    Carrier. A person who engages in the transportation of articles or materials by rail, highway, water or air. 
    City's engineer. The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant or such other person or entity designated by the city manager to undertake the responsibility and authority given the city's engineer in this article. 
    Dealer. A person engaged in the wholesale or retail business of buying and selling explosives; provided, that should a manufacturer-distributor make sales to users, such manufacturer shall not be required to obtain an additional license as a dealer. 
    Decibel (dB). The unit of sound pressure commonly used to measure airblast from explosives. The decibel sound pressure measured linearly. 
    Explosives. Any mixture, compound or material capable of producing an explosion, including, but not limited to, dynamite, nitroglycerin, trinitrotoluene, blasting caps and detonators, but not including cartridges for firearms, and not including fireworks. 
    Ground vibration. A shaking of the ground caused by the elastic wave emanating from a blast. 
    Handler. An individual who assists the user or blaster and who is licensed to handle but not to purchase, possess or detonate explosives. 
    Highway. Any public street, alley or road. 
    Limited blaster. A person restricted to noncommercial blasting, not for hire, and who does not operate at a quarry site. 
    Magazine. Any building or structure approved for the storage or explosives. 
    Manufacturer-distributor. A person engaged in the manufacture or production and distribution of explosives to others for resale or use. 
    Particle velocity. A measure of ground vibration. Describes the velocity at which a particle of ground vibrates when excited by a seismic wave. 
    Person. Any natural person, partnership, association, corporation, or legal entity, including farmers. 
    Public conveyance. Any railway car, cab, bus, airplane, or other vehicle transporting passengers for hire. 
    Purchase. Shall include acquisition of any explosive by a person with or without consideration. 
    Sale. In its various forms, shall include delivery of an explosive with or without consideration. 
    Seismologist. An individual or firm specializing in the measurement and evaluation of short-term air and ground vibrations produced through the detonation of explosives. The seismologist shall have experience in instrumentation, explosives, and the effects of vibration upon structures and a minimum of five (5) years' experience supervising and/or monitoring the use of explosives. 
    Small arms ammunition. Any shotgun, rifle or handgun ammunition. 
    Special industrial explosive device. Any explosive powerpak containing an explosive charge in the form of a cartridge or construction device. The term includes, but is not limited to, explosive rivets, explosive bolts, explosive charges for driving pins or studs, cartridges for explosive-actuated power tools, and charges of explosives used in jet tapping of open hearth furnaces and jet perforation of oil well casings. 
    Special industrial high explosive material. Sheets extrusions, pellets and packages of high explosives, containing dynamite, trinitrotoluene, pentaerythritoltetranitrate, cylotrimenthylenetrinitramine, or similar compounds used for high energy-rate forming, expending and shaping metal fabrication, and for dismemberment and quick reduction of scrap metal. 
    Test blasting cap No. 8. One containing two (2) grams of mixture of eighty (80) percent mercury fulminate and twenty (20) percent potassium chlorate, or a cap of equivalent strength. 
    User. The person who, as an ultimate consumer of an explosive, purchases the same from a dealer or manufacturer-distributor, or acquires the possession of any explosive by any other means. A user shall be licensed in the name of one (1) or more individuals who shall be licensed in accordance with the procedure outlined herein. No sales will be made to users unless authorized by a licensed individual. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(3), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-24. - Licenses required; types. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to acquire, possess, purchase, handle, dispose of, store or use an explosive on any site without first obtaining a license issued as required by the county. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or store explosives or blasting agents or to engage in blasting at any approved site without first obtaining a user license. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to use explosives or blasting agents at an approved site without first obtaining a blaster license. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to handle explosives while assisting a user or blaster without first obtaining a handler license. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(4), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-25. - Identification card required. 
    The applicant shall carry with him or her at all times the identification card required by the county and, upon request, present it to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(5), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-26. - Violations of state laws. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of Chapter 552, Florida Statutes, or any of the regulations of the state fire marshal promulgated thereunder, shall be deemed to have violated the provisions of this article and may be prosecuted in the proper court or may be subject to revocation of his or her permit and/or license and other penalties provided for herein. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(6), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-27. - Manufacture prohibited unless authorized. 
    The manufacture of explosives or blasting agents shall be prohibited unless such manufacture is authorized by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. This shall not apply to hand loading of small arms ammunition on a noncommercial basis. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(7), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-28. - Stolen explosives; report. 
    In the event that any explosive is stolen, misplaced, or lost, such occurrence shall be reported immediately to city code enforcement and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. The area in which the incident occurs shall be secured until an investigation has been made and the scene released by the property authority. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(8), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-29. - Unlawful sale. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or otherwise dispose of any explosive to any other person who does not have a valid license issued hereunder. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(9), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-30. - Storage. 
    Explosives, including, but not limited to, special industrial high explosive materials, shall not be stored within the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(10), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-31. - Transportation. 
(a)  Public conveyances. Explosives shall not be transported on public conveyances. 
(b)  Vehicle requirements. Vehicles used for transporting explosives shall be strong enough to carry the load without difficulty and shall be in good mechanical condition. If vehicles do not have a closed body, the body shall be covered with a flameproof and moisture-proof tarpaulin or other effective protection against moisture and sparks. Such vehicles shall have tight floors and exposed spark-producing metal and the inside of the body shall be covered with wood or other nonsparking material to prevent contact with packages of explosives. Packages of explosives shall not be loaded above the sides of open-body vehicles. 
(c)  Trailers. The attachment of any type of trailer behind a truck, a tractor-semitrailer, or truck-full-trailer combination transporting explosives is prohibited. Explosives shall not be transported on any pole trailer. 
(d)  Fire extinguishers. Every vehicle, when used for transporting explosives, shall be equipped with not less than two (2) approved type fire extinguishers, suitable for use on flammable liquid fires, filled and ready for immediate use, and located near the driver's seat. 
(e)  Monthly inspections. It shall be the duty of the person to whom a permit has been issued to transport explosives over the highways of the city to inspect monthly those vehicles employed by him or her to determine that: 
(1)  Fire extinguishers are filled and in operating condition. 
(2)  Electric wires are insulated and securely fastened. 
(3)  The motor, chassis and body are reasonably clean and free of excessive grease and oil. 
(4)  The fuel tank and fuel line are securely fastened and are not leaking. 
(5)  Brakes, lights, horn, windshield wipers and steering mechanism are functioning properly. 
(6)  Tires are properly inflated and free of defects. 
(7)  The vehicle is in proper condition for transporting explosives. 
(f)  Spark-producing metals. Spark-producing metals or spark-producing metal tools shall not be carried in the body of a vehicle transporting explosives. 
(g)  Federal regulations. Only those dangerous articles authorized to be loaded with explosives by the appropriate federal agency regulations shall be carried in the body of a vehicle transporting explosives. 
(h)  Smoking, flame-producing devices. No person shall smoke or carry matches or any other flame-producing device while in or near a vehicle transporting explosives; or drive, load or unload any such vehicle in a careless or reckless manner. 
(i)  Drivers. Vehicles transporting explosives shall be in the custody of drivers who are physically fit, careful, capable, reliable and who carry a valid, up-to-date chauffeur's license where applicable, not addicted to the use or under the influence of intoxicants or narcotics, and not less than eighteen (18) years of age. They shall be familiar with state and county traffic regulations, and the provisions of this article governing the transportation of explosives. 
(j)  Placarding. Every vehicle transporting explosives shall be marked or placarded on both sides, front and rear, with the word "Explosives" in letters not less than three (3) inches high on a contrasting background. 
(k)  Blasting or electric caps. Blasting caps or electric blasting caps shall not be transported over the highways of the city on the same vehicle with other explosives, except by permission of the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
(l)  Distance between vehicles. Vehicles transporting explosives and traveling in the same direction shall not be driven within three hundred (300) feet of each other. 
(m)  Routing. Vehicles transporting explosives shall be routed to avoid congested traffic and densely populated areas. 
(n)  Unattended vehicles. Vehicles transporting explosives shall not be left unattended at any time. 
(o)  Unauthorized passengers. Unauthorized persons shall not ride on vehicles transporting explosives. 
(p)  Accidents, etc. The fire and police departments shall be promptly notified when a vehicle transporting explosives is involved in an accident, breaks down, or catches fire. Only in the event of such an emergency shall the transfer of explosives from one vehicle to another vehicle be allowed on highways within the city and only when qualified supervision is provided. Except in such an emergency, a vehicle transporting explosives shall not be parked before reaching its destination on highways within the city or adjacent to or in proximity to any bridge, tunnel, dwelling, building or place where people work, congregate or assemble. 
(q)  Deliveries. Delivery shall be made to authorized persons and into approved magazines or approved temporary storage or handling areas. 
(r)  Repairs, storage. Vehicles containing explosives shall not be taken into a garage or repair shop for repairs or storage. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(11), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-32. - Use and handling. 
(a)  Hours of operation for blasting. Blasting operations shall be conducted between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. on weekdays, not including Saturdays and Sundays, and legal holidays recognized by the city or county, on which days no blasting shall take place. The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, or city commission may further restrict these hours should it determine that to be necessary to further the purpose and intent of this article. 
(b)  Qualified personnel. The handling and firing of explosives shall be performed by the person possessing a blaster license to use explosives or by license holders under his or her direct supervision who are at least eighteen (18) years old. 
(c)  Drugs, intoxicants. No person shall handle explosives while under the influence of intoxicants or narcotics. 
(d)  Smoking, etc. No person shall smoke or carry matches while handling explosives or while in the vicinity thereof. 
(e)  Open flames. No open flame light shall be used in the vicinity of explosives. 
(f)  Notice to utility companies. Whenever blasting is being conducted in the vicinity of gas, electric, water, fire alarm, telephone, telegraph or steam utilities, the blaster shall notify the appropriate representatives of such utilities at least twenty-four (24) hours in advance of blasting, specifying the location and intended time of such blasting. Verbal notice shall be confirmed with written notice. In an emergency, this time limit may be waived by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
(g)  Recognized good practice. Blasting operations shall be conducted in accordance with nationally recognized good practice. 
(h)  Precautions prior to blast. Before a blast is fired the person in charge shall make certain that all surplus explosives are in a safe place, all persons and vehicles are at a safe distance or under sufficient cover, and a loud warning signal has been sounded. 
(i)  Accidental discharge of electric blasting caps. Due precautions shall be taken to prevent accidental discharge of electric blasting caps from current induced by radio or radar transmitters, lightning, adjacent power lines, dust storms, or other sources of extraneous electricity. These precautions shall include: 
(1)  The suspension of all blasting operations and removal of persons from the blasting area during the approach and progress of an electric storm. 
(2)  The posting of signs warning against the use of mobile radio transmitters on all roads within three hundred fifty (350) feet of the blasting operations. 
(3)  Compliance with nationally recognized good practice when blasting within one and one-half (11/2) miles of broadcast of high-power shortwave radio transmitters. 
(j)  Congested areas, etc. When blasting is done in congested areas or in close proximity to a building, structure, railway, highway or any other installation that may be damaged, the blast shall be covered before firing, with a mat constructed so that it is capable of preventing rock from being thrown into the air. 
(k)  Tools used to open packages. Tools used for opening packages of explosives shall be constructed of nonsparking materials. 
(l)  Empty boxes, packing materials, etc. Empty boxes and paper and fibre packing materials which have previously contained high explosives shall not be used again for any purpose, but shall be destroyed by burning at an approved isolated location out-of-doors, and no person shall be nearer than one hundred (100) feet after the burning has started. 
(m)  Abandonment. Explosives shall not be abandoned. 
(n)  Parking of personal vehicles. Personal vehicles shall not be stopped or parked within five hundred (500) feet of a magazine or blasting site. The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, may waive this provision for certain vehicles as requested by the user in a written application. This section is not intended to exclude vehicles used in the blasting or quarrying operation. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(12), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-33. - Blasting agents. 
    Unless otherwise set forth herein, blasting agents shall be transported, stored, and used in the same manner as explosives. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(13), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-34. - Transportation of blasting agents with explosives. 
    When blasting agents are transported in the same vehicle with explosives, all of this article shall be complied with. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(14), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-35. - Blasting permit-Within limits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, through himself, herself or a blaster, to blast, fire, detonate or use any amount of explosive within the territorial limits of the county without first obtaining a blasting permit as hereinafter provided by this section; provided, that in any event, it shall be unlawful for any person to blast, fire, detonate or use any amount of explosives which: 
(1)  Would result in a vector sum particle velocity in excess of five-tenths (0.5) inch per second when measured on the ground at the nearest building or structure not owned by the permittee, or at a location identified by the seismologist of record and city code enforcement and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant; or 
(2)  Would result in an airblast level in excess of the following: 
0.1 Hz high-pass system ..... 134 dB 
2 Hz high-pass system ..... 133 dB 
5 or 6 Hz high-pass system ..... 129 dB 
C-slow (events less than 2-second duration) ..... 105 dB 
(3)  Would require placing explosives within ten (10) feet or less of the existing grade for the purpose of excavating shallow trenches for utility lines, telephone poles, etc. 
Deviation from the limits set forth in this section shall be accepted by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, upon certification by the seismologist that a higher particle velocity will not exceed the guidelines set forth for thresholds of damage per the bureau of mines and as modified by county ordinances and all regulations adopted pursuant thereto. The use of any explosives that result in a greater vector sum particle velocity or airblast than described above would constitute a public nuisance and therefore be detrimental to the public health, welfare and safety of this city. 
(b)  Peak particle velocity shall be measured as the true vector sum (resultant peak particle velocity) in three (3) mutually perpendicular planes in one (1) instant of time. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(15), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-36. - Same-Issuance; requirements. 
    No blasting shall be conducted unless a permit is issued by the county and the city. 
(1)  Such permits shall be issued by the city only after: 
a.  Payment of a fee as established by the city commission; and 
b.  Compliance with all county ordinances and regulations as set forth in Broward County Code of Ordinances, Chapter 12, as amended, and any administrative rules adopted pursuant thereto. 
c.  Establishment of a cost recovery fund, in an amount determined necessary by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, to retain experts to assist the city in implementing and enforcing the provisions of this article. The cost recovery fund shall be established prior to issuance of any permit and shall be replenished when deemed necessary in the reasonable discretion of the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant to assure that there are sufficient funds to pay for the expertise needed to implement and enforce this article, including, but not limited to, payments to another governmental entity to act as or advise the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant and payments to experts to assist the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. Funds received by the city may only be used for the purposes of processing, implementing, and enforcing the applications and actions governed by this article. 
d.  The filing of an application on a form prescribed by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, signed and sworn to by the applicant, showing the applicant's name and address, that he or she holds a valid state license and license required by this article and the location or locations where such blasting is to be performed, that blasting at such location is authorized or permitted pursuant to county and city zoning regulations, the distance between the location of the proposed blasting and any improved property, and that the applicant submits to the jurisdiction of the city and county for enforcement of all provisions of this article. 
e.  Submittal of a cash bond or letter or credit in a form acceptable to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant in the minimum amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). The security must be endorsed to provide the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant with thirty (30) days' notice of cancellation and/or restriction. The balance on the security must remain at a minimum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) during the term of security. If at any time during its term, the security is reduced to an amount below twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00), including a reduction as set forth herein, the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant shall immediately suspend the blasting permit until such time as the security amount equals or exceeds twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). The security shall not be released until the latter of sixty-one (61) days after the applicant's blasting permit expires or until all complaints against the applicant filed with the county or the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant and subsequent appeals are finalized and the appeal period lapses. The city may dispense with this requirement, in its sole discretion, if such satisfactory security is posted and maintained with the county; and 
f.  Compliance with the notice and inspection provisions set forth in subsections (3) and (4) below; and 
g.  Submission of satisfactory evidence to demonstrate that the applicant has obtained general liability insurance in an amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) of general liability and an umbrella liability policy of at least five million dollars ($5,000,000.00) against any liability arising from any activity or operation incidental to the operation. The insurance policy must be issued in the name of the applicant and shall be in a form acceptable to the city. The city shall be an additional insured and receive thirty (30) days' notice of any cancellation of the policy. 
h.  Participation by the applicant and the seismologist of record in a pre-blast conference with the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, in which the applicant shall demonstrate the hardship which necessitates blasting. The city and county pre-blast conferences may be consolidated into one (1). The applicant shall present engineering data including, but not limited to, test borings: depth, density and strata of the underlying soils, accompanied by an engineer's evaluation of the data in relation to the American Society of Testing of Material (ASTM) D 1586 Standards of Hardness, location of projects, preliminary blasting design, size of lakes, estimated fill to be removed, and the established time of completion. 
i.  Any other pertinent and reasonable information deemed by such city engineer (or city commission) to be necessary for the issuance of such permit. 
j.  Approval of the city permit is within the discretion of the city commission which has sole jurisdiction to issue city blasting permits except as noted in (b) below. The county permit shall be issued as set forth in Chapter 12, Broward County Code of Ordinances. 
k.  The city receives evidence that the permittee complies with the requirements of a drug-free work place. 
(2)  The issuance of a blasting permit shall not authorize blasting in any area or location where the same is prohibited by any zoning regulations or other law, and shall be limited to the location designated in the application; however, if the amount of explosives to be used at any one (1) time, whether fired or detonated as a single charge or by delay series, does not exceed the total explosive power or capacity of two (2) pounds of forty (40) percent dynamite, the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant is authorized to issue a blasting permit for the use of such amount of explosives without the same being limited to a particular location. The firing, detonating or exploding of any quantity of explosives on or against a boulder, rock, strata, stump, tree or other object, or on the ground surface or in the open air and not confined in a bore, hole or any blasting commonly referred to as mud-capping or abode blasting, is prohibited unless, upon application and the payment of the required fee, a person is granted a special permit for each and every location where such blasting is to be performed. 
(3)  Pre-blast inspections. 
a.  Prior to receiving a blasting permit, a list of all pre-blast inspections performed shall be provided to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. Pre-blast inspections are required for structures if either or both of the following conditions have been satisfied: 
1.  The calculated scaled distance of the structure is one hundred fifty (150) or less from the pending blast, as determined by using the following formula: 
Scaled Distance = D 
W1/2 
This ratio is used to predict ground vibrations and is equal to the distance "D" from the blast to the point of concern divided by the square root of the charge weight "W" of explosive delay; and/or 
2.  The structure is within five thousand, two hundred eighty (5,280) feet of the pending blast. 
b.  Notice shall be given to each property owner prior to conduct of the pre-blast inspection. The notice shall specify that blasting shall occur, that an inspection shall occur, and the phone number for obtaining information on the blast. Pre-blast inspections shall consist of complete documentation of the visible interior and exterior defects observed at the structure. The format shall be such that the overall location of the defects may be identified in relation to the surrounding structure. The defects, as observed, shall be photographed in detail so that the location may be determined at a later date. Reporting shall be made in a format of eight and one-half by eleven-inch or eight and one-half by fourteen-inch paper to accommodate copying, interior photographs of the structure and appurtenances showing defects shall be produced as either individual photographs or, at a minimum, contact print. Interior and exterior photographs of the structure and appurtenances containing defects must be identified as to the location and date taken. Applicants shall provide a qualified independent seismologist, as defined by Chapter 12 of the Broward County Code of Ordinances and approved by the county, to perform pre-blast inspections to structures within the notification radius described in subsection (3)a above prior to the commencement of blasting operations. 
c.  The blaster of record must offer to inspect all structures within one (1) mile of the pending blast prior to the permit being issued. The blaster of record or his/her designee shall also communicate with the developers or builders in the area to inspect any structures being erected or in existence. All inspection reports, documents and photographs, including negatives or contact prints, must be retained by the blaster of record or his/her designee for a period of three (3) years from the date the blasting permit expires. 
(4)  Pre-blast notifications (blasting commencement notification). 
a.  The applicant shall notify residents who have not received a pre-blast inspection of the pending blast at least ten (10) days prior to the commencement of the blasting. 
b.  Notification shall be distributed to all properties with a minimum distance of one thousand, five hundred feet (1,500) from the excavation perimeter or, where the notification radius is in excess of the minimum, notifications shall be distributed to those structures within a radius calculated for a scaled distance of one hundred fifty (150), plus an additional fifty (50) percent. 
c.  Notice shall be effected in either of the following methods: 
1.  Providing a written brochure or letter form, its contents pre-approved by the county, that shall explain the blasting which will take place, its effect on the residents, their ability to obtain a pre-blast inspection and the procedure for making damage claims, as set forth herein. The brochure shall be mailed or placed on the front door of each individual residence within the notification area, no less than ten (10) days prior to the commencement of blasting. 
2.  Conducting a pre-blast meeting no less than ten (10) days prior to the commencement of blasting for all residents within the notification area. At the pre-blast meeting, the applicant, or his or her designee, shall explain the blasting which will take place, its effects on the residents, their ability to obtain a pre-blast inspection, and the procedure for making damage claims, as set forth herein. 
d.  If blasting is suspended in an area for a period of ninety (90) days or longer, renotification of all residents shall be accomplished at least five (5) days prior to the commencement of blasting. 
e.  In order to determine compliance with these regulations, the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, with the seismologist of record, shall review the written inspection reports and the photographs at the pre-blast meeting or prior to the issuance of the permit. With the approval of the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, this requirement may be satisfied through a meeting with the county, as required in Chapter 12 of the Broward County Code and county regulations. The seismologist of record shall provide the county and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant with a formal reporting of those structures inspected. Copies of the photographs and written inspection reports shall be maintained by the seismologist for a period of three (3) years from the date the blasting permit expires, but shall be available for review by the division, upon request. 
f.  At least ten (10) days prior to the commencement of blasting activity, signs shall be placed on the blasting site stating that blasting will occur and that further information may be obtained by calling a telephone line identified on the sign. The exact number, placement, and size of the signs will be determined by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
g.  At least five (5) days prior to the commencement of blasting operations, applicants shall provide all residents within five thousand, two hundred eight (5,280) feet of the blasting area with a schedule of when blasting will occur. The blasting schedule shall state the dates and time windows in which blasting will occur. Time windows shall be limited and determined by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant and the explosives contractor. The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, shall be provided with a copy of the blasting schedule. 
h.  A copy of the written inspection reports shall be provided to the property owner within twenty (20) days of the inspection date. 
(5)  All blasting permits shall expire on December 31 of each year. Renewals for permits issued after March 3, 1998, shall be subject to the ordinance in effect at the time of renewal. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(16), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-37. - Limitations and conditions. 
(a)  The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant shall impose on each blasting permit issued by the city code enforcement division such limitations and conditions as to the period of time for which any permit is valid. 
(b)  In determining and imposing such reasonable conditions, the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant shall be governed by preventing damage to property, preventing personal injury or loss of life, protecting the public health, welfare and safety and the reduction of nuisance. 
(c)  The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant is authorized from time to time to change, amend or modify the imposed conditions and limitations regarding any permit in order to meet the purpose for which they were imposed if changing conditions or circumstances or unanticipated impacts or effects so dictate, after considering the guides above enumerated; and it is intended that the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant (or city commission) may impose more restrictive conditions and limitations, if circumstances and conditions in the area concerned so warrant or prove to be necessary to carry out the purpose for which the conditions and limitations were imposed. In like manner, if such condition and limitations are found by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant (or city commission) to be too restrictive, the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant (or city commission) may modify them accordingly within the bounds of the purposes for which they were imposed. However, the imposed limitations and conditions as to the amount of explosives permitted in any permit shall not be increased by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant until and unless the permittee shall first demonstrate to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant by due, recognized and proper proof that the desired increase would not in any event provide or result in a vector sum particle velocity in excess of five-tenths (0.5) inch per second, as prescribed herein. The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant shall require, in order to protect the public health, welfare or safety, the permittee to submit a recognized instrument test for any blasting operations to ascertain that the above-described limits are not exceeded at the nearest building or structure. It is the intent of this article to permit the use of an amount of explosive which will result in vibrations up to, but not exceeding, the above-described limits. 
(d)  The blaster shall provide, at his or her cost, a continuous monitoring seismic instrument at each site. Such instrument may be removed from a site, after written notice has been given to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, when the blasting at the site has been completed or indefinitely suspended. 
(e)  Blasting shall be halted if blast velocity exceeds thirty-three-one-hundredths (0.33) inch per second. Blasting may resume when a letter is provided by the permittee identifying a revised blasting methodology which reduces blast velocity to the thirty-three-one-hundredths (0.33) IPS level. 
(f)  The following requirements shall apply to all blasting operations within the distances from the nearest occupied structure, as described below: 
(1)  Zero (0) to one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet from nearest occupied structure. 
a.  The applicant shall submit the following to the city code enforcement division and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
1.  A blasting plan for the specific explosives indicating the location and loading method. 
2.  An overall site plan identifying the X-Y coordinates of all blasts proposed for detonation. Following blasts, the site plan shall be resubmitted identifying the actual location of the blasts. 
3.  The locations of instruments to be used to measure the blast. Instruments shall be required at the closest occupied structure and at the one-thousand-foot distance. 
4.  Measurements from the instruments of the seismologist of record within two (2) hours subsequent to detonation of all blasts. 
b.  The applicant shall: 
1.  Stem all blast holes with suitable material to confine the gaseous products of detonation. 
2.  Backfill the "borehole" surrounding the blast tube to ensure stability of the ground surface. 
3.  Cover or bury nonelectric surface detonators. 
4.  Complete skip drilling practices where limited patterns are to be detonated. 
5.  Ensure charges are at the specific depth originally placed prior to the detonation of multiple blasts. 
(2)  One thousand, five hundred (1,500) feet to two thousand six hundred forty (2,640) feet from nearest occupied structure. 
a.  The applicant shall submit the following to the code enforcement division and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
1.  A blasting plan for the specific explosives indicating the location and loading method. 
2.  An overall site plan identifying the X-Y coordinates of all blasts proposed for detonation. Following blasts, the site plan shall be resubmitted identifying the actual location of the blasts. 
3.  Measurements from the instruments of the seismologist of record on a daily basis with a minimum of two (2) hours prior to the scheduling of the next blast. 
b.  The applicant shall: 
1.  Stem all blast holes with suitable material to confine the gaseous products of detonation. 
2.  Backfill the "borehole" surrounding the blast tube to ensure stability of the ground surface. 
3.  Cover or bury nonelectric surface detonators. 
4.  Complete skip drilling practices where limited patterns are to be detonated. 
5.  Ensure charges are at the specific depth originally placed prior to the detonation of multiple blasts. 
(3)  Two thousand, six hundred forty (2,640) feet and greater from the nearest occupied structure. 
a.  The applicant shall submit: 
1.  A blasting plan for the specific explosives indicating the location and loading method. 
2.  An overall site plan identifying the X-Y coordinates of all blasts proposed for detonation. Following blasts, the site plan shall be resubmitted identifying the actual location of the blasts. 
3.  Weekly reports on instrument measurements if particle velocities are less than fifty (50) percent of the maximum permitted of five-tenths (0.5) inches per second. If the particle velocities are less than twenty-five (25) percent of the maximum permitted standard, monthly reports may be submitted. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(17), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-38. - Blasting records. 
(a)  Any and all users of explosives shall keep daily records for a period of three (3) years of all blasting performed on a form or forms prescribed by the county, which shall be provided to the city code enforcement division and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant on a daily basis. 
(b)  The minimum data to be shown on such record shall be: 
(1)  Name and location of blasting site. 
(2)  Location of the blast pattern by state plane coordinates or other grid system approved by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
(3)  Date and time of firing. 
(4)  Arrangements and spacing of charges. 
(5)  The amount of explosive for each blast or delay series. 
(6)  Delay interval. 
(7)  Name of person in charge of loading and firing. 
(8)  Blasting permit number, and signature and title of person making report. 
Records of instrument readings, as required herein, shall be analyzed by an independent recognized seismologist and shall be reported by him or her to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant with complete and full details, monthly or upon demand. 
All original records required by this section will be the property of the blasting company with a copy certified by a seismologist furnished to the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant. 
(c)  Each instrument shall be calibrated annually, preferably on a shaking table, and such calibration shall be certified, except for instruments which are certified as self-calibrating. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(18), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-39. - Disciplinary proceedings and penalty for violation. 
(a)  There is hereby created, for the purpose of conducting disciplinary proceedings pursuant to Chapter 12, Broward County Code of Ordinances and the regulations adopted pursuant thereto, the position of hearing officer. The hearing officer shall be selected in the manner prescribed by Chapter 12, Broward County Code of Ordinances. The process for hearings set forth in Chapter 12, Broward County Code of Ordinances, shall serve as the process for the city and act on its behalf in enforcing the requirements set forth herein. 
(b)  The city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant or the city code enforcement division is hereby authorized to initiate disciplinary proceedings (pursuant to the process set forth in Chapter 12, Broward County Code of Ordinances and the administrative regulations adopted pursuant thereto) against a permit holder for the following reasons: 
(1)  Noncompliance with any order of the issuing authority within the time specified in such order. 
(2)  Violation of any of the provisions of this part or the administrative policy of the county relating to blasting. 
(3)  In the event that the permit applicant and/or the license holder is under indictment for, or has been convicted of, a crime punishable by imprisonment for a term exceeding one (1) year. 
(4)  In the event the applicant is a fugitive from justice. 
(5)  In the event the applicant or licensee is an unlawful user of, or is addicted to, narcotics or dangerous drugs. 
(6)  In the event the applicant or licensee has been adjudicated as mentally incompetent. 
(7)  In the event the permit applicant or licensee holder suffers from a mental or physical defect that would reasonably interfere with his or her safe handling of explosives. 
(8)  Violation by the permit applicant or license holder of Chapter 552, Florida Statutes, regulations of the state fire marshal promulgated thereunder, or the city's blasting ordinance and/or policy(ies) (which includes all county ordinances and regulations adopted pursuant thereto). 
(9)  In the event that false information was given or a misrepresentation was made to obtain the permit or license. 
(c)  Nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant (or city commission) from immediately revoking or suspending a permit or license when, in his or her opinion, the alleged violation of the permit or license holder presents a serious threat to life safety, or a repeat violation. "Repeat violation" shall mean a violation of a code or ordinance provision by a person whom the hearing officer has previously found to have violated the same provision within the five (5) years prior to the violation. Where a license or permit has been revoked or suspended pursuant to the provisions of this section, a disciplinary proceeding shall be scheduled at the next regularly scheduled hearing or as soon thereafter as possible. Unless waived by the permit applicant or license holder, no hearing shall be scheduled sooner than ten (10) days from the date the license holder or permit applicant is served with the notice of hearing. A person whose permit or license has been revoked shall not be eligible to receive another blasting permit or license until it is determined by the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant that the applicant has provided sufficient safeguards to ensure that a repeat violation of this article does not occur. 
(d)  Appeal from a failure to reissue a blasting permit pursuant to paragraph (c) may be made in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(e)  The city or city code enforcement division shall serve a notice of hearing on the permit holder which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Name of the permit applicant or license holder; 
(2)  The nature of the hearing or proceeding; 
(3)  The time, date and place of the hearing or proceeding; 
(4)  A statement that "failure to attend may result in a finding being made adverse to your interests, which may include, but is not limited to, reduction of the security posted with the City of Parkland." 
(5)  That all parties may be represented by counsel; 
(6)  That all parties shall be given an opportunity to present witnesses and evidence in support of their position; and 
(7)  A statement that "if you decide to appeal any decision made by the hearing officer with respect to any matter considered at such proceeding, you will need a record of the proceeding, and that, for such purpose, you may need to ensure that a verbatim record of the proceeding is made, which record includes the testimony and evidence upon which the appeal is to be based." 
(f)  Violations of this article shall be punished as provided herein or as provided in the city Code. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(19), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-40. - Blasting complaints. 
(a)  In the event a person alleges damages resulting from blasting and wishes to have the issue resolved by a hearing officer, he or she shall have sixty (60) days from the date of the blast to file a complaint with the county and the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant on a form provided by the county. The complaint shall state on its face that, by filing the complaint with the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant, the complainant is submitting to the jurisdiction of the hearing officer for a determination of the damage claim(s). The complaint process contained in this article however, shall not be available for damage claims which have been previously adjudicated or determined by a municipal agency or board pursuant to the municipality's blasting ordinance, resolution, regulation or policy. 
(b)  The complaint shall be referred to the seismologist of record via facsimile. The seismologist shall determine the relationship between the claimed defects and blasting. This evaluation shall be based upon measured particle velocity levels and the results of any pre-blast and post-blast inspections. 
(c)  Upon receipt of the complaint by the seismologist of record, the seismologist shall have thirty (30) days to conduct an inspection of the claim, prepare a report and forward the necessary documentation and report to the applicant and/or applicant's insurance company. Copies of the liability determination from the applicant or applicant's insurance company shall be forwarded to the county, the city's engineer or designee, or qualified engineering consultant and the complainant. The record of complaints filed with the city, if any, shall be provided by the city to the county within seven (7) calendar days from receipt of the complaint. 
(d)  After a determination is made by the applicant or applicant's insurance company, or if no determination is made by the applicant's insurance company, the matter shall be set for hearing at the next regularly scheduled hearing or as soon thereafter as possible; provided, however, that no hearing shall be scheduled sooner than ten (10) days from the date the applicant is served with the notice of hearing. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(20), 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 2, 6-3-2009) 
Sec. 14-41. - Blasting complaint hearings. 
    For all complaints to be heard by the hearing officer related to damages, hearings shall be noticed and held, and decisions and penalties enforced, by the county in accordance with the terms and conditions and penalties set forth in Broward County Code of Ordinances, Chapter 12, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(21), 3-3-1998) 
Sec. 14-42. - Conduct of hearings. 
    Hearings shall be conducted in accordance with county ordinances and all regulations adopted pursuant thereto. 
(Ord. No. 98-06, § 1(22), 3-3-1998) 
Chapter 19 - TAXATION AND FINANCE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 19-1-19-9. - Reserved. 
Sec. 19-10. - Public records. 
(a)  A charge for copying public records for the city shall be fifteen cents ($0.15) per page. 
(b)  If the nature or volume of records to be inspected or copied requires the extensive use of information technology resources or extensive clerical or supervisory assistance, or both, the city may charge a reasonable service charge based upon the costs actually incurred by the city for such extensive use of information technology resources or personnel. Any records that take more than thirty (30) minutes to locate shall be considered extensive. Information technology resources shall be deemed to mean data processing hardware and software services, communication supplies, personnel, facility resources, maintenance and training. The costs of clerical time or information technology service time shall be billed at the employee's hourly rate plus benefits as paid by the city to the employee. 
(Ord. No. 2005-09, § 1, 5-18-2005) 
Sec. 19-11. - Administrative and/or user fees. 
(a)  It is the intent of the city commission to transfer the costs of certain city services to the individuals who are requesting the services from the city. The administrative and/or user fees charged under this section shall be set forth in a resolution adopted by the city commission. 
(b)  The listing of administrative and/or user fees in this chapter may not be all inclusive and therefore, other applicable Code of Ordinance chapters and/or provisions may apply in addition to the fees designated in this chapter. 
(c)  All fees included in this chapter shall be permitted to be increased yearly, without city commission approval, no greater than the Consumer Price Index ("CPI"). Upon approval by the city commission, through a resolution, an administrative and/or user fee can be increased above the CPI. 
(d)  All fees adopted per this chapter shall be increased on October 1 of each respective year unless noted otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2007-17, § 2, 9-19-2007) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-17, § 2, adopted Sept. 19, 2007, amended by adding § 19-11. The former § 19-11 pertained to requests for information concerning outstanding city liens and derived from Ord. No. 93-11, § 1, adopted July 21, 1993; Ord. No. 2005-09, § 1, adopted May 18, 2005. 
Sec. 19-12. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2007-17, § 3, adopted Sept. 19, 2007, deleted § 19-12, which pertained to charges for preparing and recording liens and lien satisfactions and derived from Ord. No. 93-11, § 2, adopted Aug. 21, 1993.

ARTICLE III. - GROSS PREMIUMS RECEIPTS TAX ON CASUALTY INSURANCE POLICIES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Inasmuch as Ord. No. 82, §§ 1, 2, adopted Dec. 7, 1983, did not specify manner of codification, such provisions have been included herein as Art. III, §§ 19-21, 19-22, at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 19-21. - Assessed. 
    There is hereby assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer now engaging in or carrying on, or which shall hereafter engage in or carry on the business of insuring with respect to casualty risks, as shown by the records of the Department of Insurance, an excise or license tax in addition to any license tax or excise now levied by the City of Parkland, which said tax shall be in the amount of .85 percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies, covering property within the corporate limits of the City of Parkland. 
(Ord. No. 82, § 1, 12-7-1983; Ord. No. 2004-08, § 1, 3-8-2004) 
Sec. 19-22. - When due and payable. 
    The license or excise tax herein levied shall be due and payable annually on July 1 of each year hereafter. 
(Ord. No. 82, § 2, 12-7-1983; Ord. No. 2004-08, § 2, 3-8-2004) 
Sec. 19-23. - Excise tax on property insurance premiums levied. 
(1)  There is hereby assessed and imposed on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer in the city, engaged in or carrying on the business of insuring property against loss or damage by fire or tornado, an excise or license tax amounting to 1.85 percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policy holders on all premiums collected on fire and tornado insurance policies covering property within the city. 
(2)  The excise tax provided for in this section shall be payable and collected in the manner provided for by state law providing for the creation and administration of a firefighter's pension fund. 
(3)  The tax assessed and imposed under this section shall be in addition to all other taxes now levied by the city, and is a tax collected by the state, which will hereafter be credited to the city under state law. 
(Ord. No. 2006-18, § 2, 7-5-2006) 
Secs. 19-24-19-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 94-10, adopted Sept. 21, 1994, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, codification of §§ 1-8 of said ordinance as §§ 19-41-19-48 was at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 19-41. - Levied; amount; time of payment. 
    There is hereby levied by the city, against each and every purchaser or person using electricity, a tax in the amount of ten (10) percent of the payments received by the seller of the taxable item from the purchaser for the purchase of the service. Such tax shall, in every case, be paid by the purchaser, for the use of the city, to the seller of such electricity at the time of paying the charge therefor to the seller thereof, but not less than monthly. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 1, 9-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-02, § 1, 4-16-1997) 
Sec. 19-42. - Duty of seller to collect; liability; discontinuance of service for failure to pay bill. 
    It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity to collect from the purchaser for the use of the city the tax hereby levied at the time of collecting the selling price charged for each transaction, and to report and pay over, on or before the twentieth day of each fiscal month, to the city finance director, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding fiscal month. It shall be unlawful for any seller to collect the price of any purchase of electricity without, at the same time, collecting the tax hereby levied in respect to such purchase or purchases, unless such seller shall elect to assume and pay such tax without collecting the same from the purchaser. Any seller failing to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of any purchase, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay such tax, shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the same had been actually paid to the seller, and the city manager shall cause to be brought all suits and actions and to take all proceedings in the name of the city as may be necessary for the recovery of such tax; the seller shall not be liable for the payment of such tax upon uncollected bills. If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge and tax hereby imposed and as hereby required, on account of the purchase for which such charge is made, or either, the seller shall have and is hereby vested with the right, power and authority to immediately discontinue further service to such purchaser until the tax and the seller's bill shall have been paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 2, 9-21-1994) 
Sec. 19-43. - Records. 
    Each and every seller of electricity shall keep complete records showing all purchases in the city of such commodities or services. Such records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the date thereof and the date of payment thereof, and the records shall be kept open for inspection by the duly authorized agents of the city during business hours on all business days. Duly authorized agents of the city shall have the right, power and authority to make such transcripts thereof during such times as they may desire. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 3, 9-21-1994) 
Sec. 19-44. - Exemption from payment. 
    The United States of America, State of Florida, political subdivisions and agencies thereof, as well as any other public body and any recognized church in this state, for uses exclusively for church purposes, are hereby exempted from payment of the taxes levied by this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 4, 9-21-1994) 
Sec. 19-45. - Applicability to fuel adjustment charges. 
    The tax provided herein shall not apply to any fuel adjustment charge as set forth in Section 166.231(b), Florida Statutes (1993). 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 5, 9-21-1994) 
Sec. 19-46. - Computation of tax collected monthly. 
    In all cases where the seller of electricity collects the price thereof at monthly periods, the tax hereby levied may be computed on the aggregate amount of purchases during such period, provided that the amount of tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 6, 9-21-1994) 
Sec. 19-47. - Authority of, compliance with state law. 
    This tax on electricity imposed herein is imposed pursuant to the authority of Sections 166.231 and 166.241, Florida Statutes (1997). This article shall be constructed and applied in a manner so as to be consistent with the provisions thereof and if any court shall find that any provision of this article is in conflict with Sections 166.231 and 166.241, Florida Statutes (1997), then, in that event, the tax shall be imposed, collected, and implemented as set forth in Sections 166.231 and 166.241, Florida Statutes (1997) on electricity. All mandatory exemptions provided for in Sections 166.231 and 166.241, Florida Statutes (1997) are incorporated herein by reference; however, in any case where Sections 166.231 and 166.241, Florida Statutes (1997), does not specifically require such exemption as a matter of law, such exemption shall not apply unless specifically set forth in this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 7, 9-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-19, § 1, 10-8-1997) 
Sec. 19-48. - Penalty. 
    Any purchaser willfully failing or refusing to pay the tax hereby imposed, where the seller has not elected to assume and pay the tax, and any seller violating the provisions of this article or any officer, agent, or employee of any seller violating the provisions hereof, shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each violation. 
(Ord. No. 94-10, § 8, 9-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-02, § 2, 4-16-1997) 
Sec. 19-49. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOMESTEAD EXEMPTION 

Sec. 19-50. - Additional homestead exemption. 
(a)  Application of this section. Pursuant to and in accordance with Section 196.075, Florida Statutes, the additional homestead exemption as set forth in this section shall only apply to all taxes levied by the city. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning: 
    Household. A person or group of persons living together in a room or group of rooms as a housing unit, but the term does not include persons boarding in or renting a portion of the dwelling. 
    Household income. The adjusted gross income of all members of a household, as defined in Section 62 of the United States Internal Revenue Code. 
(c)  Amount of additional homestead exemption. Any person who meets the requirements as set forth in subsection (d) below, shall be eligible for an additional homestead exemption in the amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). Such additional homestead exemption shall not exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in accordance with Section 196.075, Florida Statutes. 
(d)  Requirements to obtain additional homestead exemption. A person who has attained the age of sixty-five (65) will be entitled to an additional homestead exemption only if the following requirements are satisfied: 
(1)  The person has legal or equitable title to real estate; and 
(2)  The person maintains thereon the permanent residence of the owner; and 
(3)  The person has attained the age of sixty-five (65); and 
(4)  The person's household income does not exceed twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00); and 
(5)  The taxpayer claiming the above exemption must submit annually to the Broward County property appraiser, not later than March 1, a sworn statement of household income on a form prescribed by the Department of Revenue. The filing of this statement must be supported by copies of any federal income tax returns for the prior year, any wage and earnings statements (W-2 forms), and any other documents required by the Department of Revenue, for each member of the household, to be submitted by June 1. The taxpayer's statement shall attest to the accuracy of such copies. The property appraiser may not grant the exemption without the required documentation. 
(e)  Household income. For purposes of subsection (d)(4) above, beginning January 1, 2001, the twenty thousand dollar ($20,000.00) household income limitation shall be adjusted annually on January 1 by the percentage change in the average cost-of-living index in the period January 1 through December 31 of the immediate prior year compared with the same period for the year prior to that. The index is the average of the monthly consumer-price-index figures for the stated twelve-month period, relative to the United States as a whole issued by the United States Department of Labor. 
(f)  [Joint title.] If title is held jointly with right of survivorship, the person residing on the property and otherwise qualifying may receive the entire amount of the additional homestead exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2003-05, § 1, 3-15-2003) 
Secs. 19-51-19-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - FIRE RESCUE SERVICES ORDINANCE[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2004-27, adopted Jan. 11, 2005, which pertained to fire rescue services did not specify manner of codification; hence these provisions with the city's permission were set out as Art. VI. 

DIVISION 1. - INTRODUCTION 

Sec. 19-101. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings, unless the context clearly otherwise requires: 
    Annual rate resolution means the resolution described in section 19-208 hereof, establishing the rate at which a fire rescue assessment for a specific fiscal year will be computed. The final assessment resolution shall constitute the annual rate resolution for the initial fiscal year in which a fire rescue assessment is imposed or reimposed. 
    Article means this fire rescue assessment ordinance. 
    Assessed property means all parcels of land included on the assessment roll that receive a special benefit from the delivery of the fire rescue services, programs or facilities identified in the initial assessment resolution or a subsequent preliminary rate resolution. 
    Assessment roll means the special assessment roll relating to a fire rescue assessment approved by a final assessment resolution pursuant to section 19-206 hereof or an annual rate resolution pursuant to section 19-208 hereof. 
    Building means any structure, whether temporary or permanent, built for support, shelter or enclosure of persons, chattel, or property of any kind, including mobile homes. This term shall include the use of land in which lot or spaces are offered for use, rent or lease for the placement of mobile homes, travel trailers, or the like for residential purposes. 
    Certificate of occupancy means the written certification issued by the city that a building is ready for occupancy for its intended use. For the purposes of this article, a set up or tie down permit or its equivalent issued for a mobile home shall be considered a certificate of occupancy. 
    City means the City of Parkland, Florida. 
    City clerk means the clerk of the city commission. 
    City commission means the city commission of the City of Parkland, Florida. 
    City manager means the chief administrative officer of the city, designated by the city commission to be responsible for coordinating fire rescue assessments or such person's designee. 
    County means Broward County, Florida. 
    Final assessment resolution means the resolution described in section 19-206 hereof which shall confirm, modify, or repeal the initial assessment resolution and which shall be the final proceeding for the initial imposition of fire rescue assessments. 
    Fire rescue assessment means a special assessment lawfully imposed by the city commission against assessed property to fund all or any portion of the cost of the provision of fire rescue services, facilities, or programs providing a special benefit to property as a consequence of possessing a logical relationship to the value, use, or characteristics of the assessed property. 
    Fire rescue assessed cost means the amount determined by the city commission to be assessed in any fiscal year to fund all or any portion of the cost of the provision of fire rescue services, facilities, or programs which provide a special benefit to assessed property, and shall include, but not be limited to, the following components: (A) the cost of physical construction, reconstruction or completion of any required facility or improvement; (B) the costs incurred in any required acquisition or purchase; (C) the cost of all labor, materials, machinery, and equipment; (D) the cost of fuel, parts, supplies, maintenance, repairs, and utilities; (E) the cost of computer services, data processing, and communications; (F) the cost of all lands and interest therein, leases, property rights, easements, and franchises of any nature whatsoever; (G) the cost of any indemnity or surety bonds and premiums for insurance; (H) the cost of salaries, volunteer pay, workers' compensation insurance, or other employment benefits; (I) the cost of uniforms, training, travel, and per diem; (J) the cost of construction plans and specifications, surveys and estimates of costs; (K) the cost of engineering, financial, legal, and other professional services; (L) the costs of compliance with any contracts or agreements entered into by the city to provide fire rescue services; (M) all costs associated with the structure, implementation, collection, and enforcement of the fire rescue assessments, including any service charges of the tax collector or property appraiser and amounts necessary to off-set discounts received for early payment of fire rescue assessments pursuant to the Uniform Assessment Collection Act or for early payment of fire rescue assessments collected pursuant to section 19-302 herein; (N) all other costs and expenses necessary or incidental to the acquisition, provision, or construction of fire rescue services, facilities, or programs, and such other expenses as may be necessary or incidental to any related financing authorized by the city commission by subsequent resolution; (O) a reasonable amount for contingency and anticipated delinquencies and uncollectible fire rescue assessments; and (P) reimbursement to the city or any other person for any moneys advanced for any costs incurred by the city or such person in connection with any of the foregoing components of fire rescue assessed cost. In the event the city also imposes an impact fee upon new growth or development for fire rescue related capital improvements, the fire rescue assessed cost shall not include costs attributable to capital improvements necessitated by new growth or development that will be paid by such impact fees. The fire rescue assessed cost shall also not include costs for the provision of emergency medical services by the city. 
    Fiscal year means that period commencing October 1 of each year and continuing through the next succeeding September 30, or such other period as may be prescribed by law as the fiscal year for the city. 
    Government property means property owned by the United States of America or any agency thereof, a sovereign state or nation, the State of Florida or any agency thereof, a county, a special district or a municipal corporation. 
    Initial assessment resolution means the resolution described in section 19-202 hereof which shall be the initial proceeding for the identification of the fire rescue assessed cost for which an assessment is to be made and for the imposition of a fire rescue assessment. 
    Maximum assessment rate means the highest rate of a fire rescue assessment established by the city commission in an initial assessment resolution or preliminary rate resolution and confirmed by the city commission in the final assessment resolution or annual rate resolution. 
    Owner shall mean the person reflected as the owner of assessed property on the tax roll. 
    Person means any individual, partnership, firm, organization, corporation, association, or any other legal entity, whether singular or plural, masculine or feminine, as the context may require. 
    Preliminary rate resolution means the resolution described in section 19-208 hereof initiating the annual process for updating the assessment roll and directing the reimposition of fire rescue assessments pursuant to an annual rate resolution. 
    Property appraiser means the Broward County Property Appraiser. 
    Tax collector means the department of finance and administrative services as described in Article IV of the Broward County Charter. 
    Tax roll means the real property ad valorem tax assessment roll maintained by the property appraiser for the purpose of the levy and collection of ad valorem taxes. 
    Uniform Assessment Collection Act means F.S. §§ 197.3632 and 197.3635 or any successor statutes authorizing the collection of non-ad valorem assessments on the same bill as ad valorem taxes, and any applicable regulations promulgated thereunder. 
(Ord. No. 2004-27, § 1.01, 1-11-2005) 
Sec. 19-102. - Interpretation. 
    Unless the context indicates otherwise, words importing the singular number include the plural number, and vice versa; the terms "hereof," "hereby," "herein," "hereto," "hereunder" and similar terms refer to this article; and the term "hereafter" means after, and the term "heretofore" means before, the effective date of this article. Words of any gender include the correlative words of the other genders, unless the sense indicates otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 2004-27, § 1.02, 1-11-2005) 
Sec. 19-103. - General findings. 
    It is hereby ascertained, determined, and declared that: 
(1)  Pursuant to Article VIII, Section 2(b), Florida Constitution, and F.S. §§ 166.021 and 166.041 the city commission has all powers of local self government to perform municipal functions and to render municipal services in a manner not inconsistent with law, and such power may be exercised by the enactment of city ordinances. 
(2)  The city commission may exercise any governmental, corporate, or proprietary power for a municipal purpose except when expressly prohibited by law, and the city commission may legislate on any subject matter on which the Florida Legislature may act, except those subjects described in (a), (b), (c), and (d) of Section 166.021(3), Florida Statutes. The subject matter of paragraphs (a), (b), (c), and (d) of Section 166.021(3), Florida Statutes, are not relevant to the imposition of assessments related to fire rescue services, facilities or programs of the city. 
(3)  The purpose of this article is to (1) provide procedures and standards for the imposition of citywide fire rescue assessments under the general home rule powers of a municipality to impose special assessments; (2) authorize a procedure for the funding of fire rescue services, facilities, or programs providing special benefits to property within the city; and (3) legislatively determine the special benefit provided to assessed property from the provision of the city's fire rescue services. 
(4)  The annual fire rescue assessments, to be imposed using the procedures provided in this article, shall constitute non-ad valorem assessments within the meaning and intent of the Uniform Assessment Collection Act. 
(5)  The fire rescue assessments to be imposed using the procedures provided in this article are imposed by the city commission, not the Broward County Board of County Commissioners, Property Appraiser or Tax Collector. The duties of the property appraiser and tax collector under the provisions of this article and the Uniform Assessment Collection Act are ministerial. 
(Ord. No. 2004-27, § 1.03, 1-11-2005) 
Sec. 19-104. - Legislative determinations of special benefit. 
    It is hereby ascertained and declared that the fire rescue services, facilities, and programs provide a special benefit to property because fire rescue services possess a logical relationship to the use and enjoyment of improved property by: (1) protecting the value and integrity of the improvements and structures through the provision of available fire rescue services; (2) protecting the life and safety of intended occupants in the use and enjoyment of property; (3) lowering the cost of fire insurance by the presence of a professional and comprehensive fire rescue program within the city; and (4) containing the spread of fire incidents occurring on vacant property with the potential to spread and endanger the structures and occupants of improved property. 
(Ord. No. 2004-27, § 1.04, 1-11-2005) 
Secs. 19-105-19-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ANNUAL FIRE RESCUE ASSESSMENTS 

Sec. 19-201. - General authority. 
(a)  The city commission is hereby authorized to impose an annual fire rescue assessment to fund all or any portion of the fire rescue assessed cost upon benefitted property at a rate of assessment based on the special benefit accruing to such property from the city's provision of fire rescue services, facilities, or programs. All fire rescue assessments shall be imposed in conformity with the procedures set forth in this division 2. 
(b)  The amount of the fire rescue assessment imposed in a fiscal year against a parcel of assessed property shall be determined pursuant to an apportionment methodology based upon a classification of property designed to provide a fair and reasonable apportionment of the fire rescue assessed cost among properties on a basis reasonably related to the special benefit provided by fire rescue services, facilities, or programs funded with assessment proceeds. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this article shall be construed to require the imposition of fire rescue assessments against government property. 
(Ord. No. 2004-27, § 2.01, 1-11-2005) 
Sec. 19-202. - Initial proceedings.
